The new server, called the IBM eServer Cluster 325, is tailored to operate as a virtualization environment--designed to create private servers in the cloud.
IBM initially announced the new platform at the recent VMWorld 2009 conference in San Francisco.
The system comprises IBM's Opteron-based eServer 325, named after the three remote memory accesses systemintesifications, system management software and storage devices that can run Linux and Windows operating systems.
IBM also developed a resource management application called Hypervisor Management Plug-In (HMP) to control and manage the server.

on Cancer (IARC), which is a WHO agency, came to the conclusion after reviewing all the evidence relating to the two types of meat consumption and cancer.
In a novel classification session a few months ago, the IARC categorized processed meat as a “carcinogenic to humans,” with a cause and effect link. As a result, the substance has been moved up from group 2A on the IARC classification hierarchy to a red-flag rating of group 1.
In the same assessment, red meat was also categorized as carcinogenic to humans. Experts are now broadly concurring with the discussions the panel had during the classification exercise.
The World Health Organization (WHO) made a similar classification towards the end of 2012 in general terms, when it was found to be a probable human carcinogen.

a fight between Republican lawmakers and the White House.
The White House and conservative U.S. lawmakers went into last-minute discussions after congressional Republicans on Thursday revealed a plan to require President Barack Obama seek a delay of implementation of major healthcare reforms — which are subsidizing insurance for more than 10% of the population -- unless the overhaul is repealed.
Republicans had demanded the offset in a proposed delay until after the November 2014 congressional elections, so they would not be viewed as having the healthcare program taken away from individuals.
The Republican framework brushes up against the limit on government debt, known as the debt ceiling. Congress faces a Sept. 28 deadline under the rules of U.S. borrowing procedures.

on-air shopping plans to spend more than $20 million on prime-time Black Friday spots, three times the amount that it spent during last year’s holiday season, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday.
QVC said the event — which runs from Thanksgiving evening to early Saturday morning — should set the tone for a strong shopping season that carries into the all-important post-Christmas season.
QVC’s Black Friday event differs from the in-store shenanigans favored by companies such as Macy’s, which hope to get shoppers through the door with slim profit margins.
Instead, experts note that QVC’s strategy — which includes coupons for products on its web site — lets retailers sell in one of the few domestic markets still with growth potential in order to plug potential holes in QVC’s seasonal revenue stream.

Keep in mind variety is the key here. You have many options to choose from, such as whey (they make kefir as well as yogurt), so do your research.

As with a lot of other beverages, tea is not a big source of fiber and you should not drink excessive amounts.
Steaming hot water and green tea? Yes please.

astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate planets with about the right conditions for life last week, researchers are pushing in a separate direction – the carbon.
The hunt for planets like Earth with potential for alien life is casting a new light on the chemical element that makes the chlorophyll in plant leaves green.
“While the Earth put a lot of water-loving bacteria on the spotlight, with ‘Habitable Zone’ planets molecules interacting with light are taking the lead roles,” says Jake Matijevic at the University of Chicago in the US.
Matijevic argues that scientists should look for places where there is a combination of three gases – water, carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide. “One can imagine the intricate network of carbon atoms quietly dancing with each other across the surface as ambient gases turn into surface materials,” Matijevic says.

First, the letter’s addressee receives the letter through the gatekeeper responsible for verifying who the letter is for. Accordingly, you don’t have discretion with how you address a letter once you are sure the letter is going to the proper person. First impressions count, though. Make sure that the letter is legible, or else it may be refused or sent back to you.
How to Write a Simple Business Envelope Address
Write the correct corporation name and type it out exactly as it appears on the company’s letterhead and the “To Whom It May Concern” letter itself. If the corporation submits a letter with a letterhead or other document with its address or contact information on it when you download it from the Internet, you can find the corporation’s contact information and office location on the letter.

She reports leaving a will, claiming $3 million in an account, and asks friends for help in getting her message out.
In actuality, the wife of one of the hackers behind the While You Were Away scam has been infiltrating Facebook hacking communities and injecting a hoax Facebook link into the conversations, pretending she’s a young woman in a bad position, according to World Security Inc. from the sun. Formed 4.6 billion years ago during the Big Bang, Earth’s crust—which gives us land and oceans (and the continents also called crust by geologists)—is a combination of magma, molten rock, and solid rock pieces.
As Earth crust generates some thermal energy, some is stored in the mantle, which is cooler than the crust yet hotter than the core. Materials in the mantle heat up as layers beneath them cool; these are carried away to the surface and form volcanoes and earthquakes.
Thermal energy of the mantle is derived mainly from radioactive decay in early primitive materials when the planetÃ¢’s background radiation was hotter, leaving a weakly heat generating remnant at the mantle. Since the steam engine is fueled by coal, in the Big Bang, a massive nuclear event formed a large amount of helium.

cells known as fibroblasts appear to work together to send a signal to the micro-environment around a cell to limit the growth or damage from genetic changes to the DNA.

Thomas Jefferson wrote about Revere's ride to the Massachusetts colonists resistance, being the inspiration for the town meeting he had attended a week earlier.

History professor Louis S. Gerry wrote about it in a book on the subject of the ride titled, Midnight Ride of Paul Revere .

Pardoned by the Pope immediately after his return to the Scottish throne in 1329, King Robert is celebrated across the country with tales of valour and personal sacrifice from battles as far apart as Bannockburn (June 1314) and his eventual independence from England.
But away from the melee of warfare he also helped to reshape Scotland – not least with the government he set up in Edinburgh Castle.
In 1316, the Treaty of Northampton marked an acceptance by the English crown that the Bruce dynasty was once again the governing family of Scotland.
Along with a renewed trademark vigour, the king would use the peace to bring order to a country plagued by factional division.

President Jimmy Carter established the first Earth Day, an observance to support environmental protection, on April 22, 1970. Millions of Americans participated.
Twenty million people — the largest group gathered in a human event — attended an Earth Day rally on the Washington Monument monument grounds in 1990, according to the book “Earth Day: The First 20 Years.”
More than 500,000 people participated in Earth Day celebrations in Switzerland in 1990.

Having Zika virus doesn’t mean a catastrophe. The dynamics are correct in treating the virus.

In building a brick wall, the first task is to state what brick you are going to build with; when it is a single brick with no apology (instead of a whole fence, as in a talk), you want to state your brick at the very beginning so your audience grasps its dimensions rapidly, so that it can allow the brick its place in the entire wall. Some bricks are meant to be bold and present themselves for discussion, some are made to fill a niche for support, some are intended to hold still or to be moved into the desired placement. Other bricks scatter down into the darkness and stain the stones below with soot.
Some brick-builders give a vow of silence on the brick’s purpose.

the keto diet requires a lot of watching macronutrients, making sure you're counting your calories and making sure you have enough protein and fat with every serving. It can be an absolute pain.
The keto diet is all about keeping your carb intake so incredibly low that it's going to force your body into a ketosis state, where your body breaks down ketone bodies from your fat stores and uses them as energy instead of the carbs you've cut out. Too many carbs and your body wants to reabsorb glucose before breaking down fats for energy. And if you keep the carbs very low (like 20 carbs per day or less) your body can happily get into ketosis.

The Gag Rule, also known as the Mexico City Policy in its original form, prohibits the distribution of federal funding – the federal government pays a portion of the cost of birth control and abortions around the world – to organizations that even discuss abortion as an option for women.
As originally proposed by Reagan, the Gag Rule prohibited all groups that provided abortions from receiving U.S. funding. Under the new policy, services such as sex education, contraception or abortions cannot use U.S. aid if a third party participates in any way (as a partner or in a consortium with the U.S. group) – even if the administrator does not participate in an abortion itself.

You need a high-quality GPS sensor to record a useful range. Lower-level devices (for example, five satellites) are a speedometer and can only be used for high error precision. High level devices are often used to position objects on large ships.

my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different shapes into the bark with scraps of chalk, sowing a fragment of orange into a sea of brown.

Keeping my tongue pressed against my cheek made me more analytical of objects, and I tried to discern how words make people see the same thing differently. A story of immense human struggle. A classic that doesn’t follow the typical Western tale. His name is Otto Turner, and he will become the richest, most powerful man the world has ever seen. From black to white, Otto did not just conquer America, he conquered the world.
The story introduces you to the strong and the weak, the slow and the fast, the beautiful and the ugly … and all of the successes and failures of a Southern black man living in a time when the black man had no rights, no one to turn to, and no hope for a future.

blog recently discussing the content quality factors considered in the web search algorithm.
They focus on two primary criteria:
the more "structured" factors (e.g., can you explain the page's content)
the more "abstraction" factors (e.g., does the page make sense or does it require extra explanations).
These both include more "traditional" factors:
internal navigational sitemaps
syntax checks (e.g., images missing alt text
They also highlight more nuanced quality factors:
caption the images you choose (i.e., don't just add the photo and name)
use a less "aggressive" alternative format rather than transparency for displaying text
include tags that are valuable to the user (e.g., one page per product is no longer required)
use the indexable HTML form to describe forms, not just labels
Use Alt Text for images

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a WHO agency, came to the conclusion after reviewing all the evidence relating to the two types of meat consumption and cancer.
In a novel classification session a few months ago, the IARC categorized processed meat as a “carcinogenic to humans,” with a cause and effect link. As a result, the substance has been moved up from group 2A on the IARC classification hierarchy to a red-flag rating of group 1.
In the same assessment, red meat was also categorized as carcinogenic to humans. Experts are now broadly concurring with the discussions the panel had during the classification exercise.
The World Health Organization (WHO) made a similar classification towards the end of 2012 in general terms, when it was found to be a probable human carcinogen.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican lawmakers and the White House.
The White House and conservative U.S. lawmakers went into last-minute discussions after congressional Republicans on Thursday revealed a plan to require President Barack Obama seek a delay of implementation of major healthcare reforms — which are subsidizing insurance for more than 10% of the population -- unless the overhaul is repealed.
Republicans had demanded the offset in a proposed delay until after the November 2014 congressional elections, so they would not be viewed as having the healthcare program taken away from individuals.
The Republican framework brushes up against the limit on government debt, known as the debt ceiling. Congress faces a Sept. 28 deadline under the rules of U.S. borrowing procedures.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend more than $20 million on prime-time Black Friday spots, three times the amount that it spent during last year’s holiday season, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday.
QVC said the event — which runs from Thanksgiving evening to early Saturday morning — should set the tone for a strong shopping season that carries into the all-important post-Christmas season.
QVC’s Black Friday event differs from the in-store shenanigans favored by companies such as Macy’s, which hope to get shoppers through the door with slim profit margins.
Instead, experts note that QVC’s strategy — which includes coupons for products on its web site — lets retailers sell in one of the few domestic markets still with growth potential in order to plug potential holes in QVC’s seasonal revenue stream.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to Sylwester Saszczerowski, executive board director and global head of portfolio management firm CIO Foodgroup.
Although China is making tremendous progress on reducing the drag from its state-owned enterprises and traditional banking sector and radical new policies such as the Chinese Bond Connect program are a positive step towards capturing more private capital from overseas markets, Saszczerowski says there are still major drags on the Mainland market which could be addressed by opening the door for foreign investors in certain segments.
An example of one of these “green shoots” is the emergence of early-stage impact investing – a relatively new idea in private equity markets but one that has already led to venture capitalist bidding frenzies for early-stage biotech start-ups in biomedical research hubs like China.

Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Jackie Kopecek on May 19, 2002, who survives.
Surviving are three stepsons; three grandchildren; and a brother.
He was a former engineer and had worked in maintenance at the Holiday Inn until his retirement in 2003. For a number of years, he served as a board member and president of the Christian Fellowship Church. He loved to barbeque and fish.
At the family's request there will be no public services and burial will be in Altoona Memorial Gardens.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would have been an automatic assumption as we don’t exactly have a reputation of being a country where women are concerned. As a result, few initiatives have been implemented to try and solve the problem – the most recent was the Parental Leave Act in 2016 – though the issue remains widely under-addressed in the media despite being a serious issue for Irish women.
When discussing these issues, it’s important to look at the American women’s experience in the area of maternal mortality and morbidity, which directly impacts our own experience at home, as infant mortality rates rise alongside those off maternal mortality rates.

Wilson threw a 13-yard touchdown pass to Golden Tate with 13 seconds left and stepped out of the way of the defense just before the clock ran out, allowing the Seahawks (10-2) to remain jointly atop the NFC with the Green Bay Packers 12-7.
Cam Newton threw for minus-1 yard and an interception after firing a 99-yard touchdown pass to Steve Smith on the Panthers' previous possession.
Carolina (3-10-1) dropped its final game in the second regular season installment of the NFL's 13-week, international series. The Packers and Seahawks defeated San Francisco and the New York Giants earlier this season.
The Seahawks' 20-17 victory Tuesday night marked the first time Green Bay and Seattle had won the NFL's first pair of international games in the same season.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate planets with about the right conditions for life last week, researchers are pushing in a separate direction – the carbon.
The hunt for planets like Earth with potential for alien life is casting a new light on the chemical element that makes the chlorophyll in plant leaves green.
“While the Earth put a lot of water-loving bacteria on the spotlight, with ‘Habitable Zone’ planets molecules interacting with light are taking the lead roles,” says Jake Matijevic at the University of Chicago in the US.
Matijevic argues that scientists should look for places where there is a combination of three gases – water, carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide. “One can imagine the intricate network of carbon atoms quietly dancing with each other across the surface as ambient gases turn into surface materials,” Matijevic says.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.

A large showy diascia with red flowers, ideal for large informal or cottage gardens.

Activities, games and puzzles are waiting to be explored by your inquisitive toddler.
If you haven’t been to your local library in a while, perhaps it’s time for a visit. Not only can you get all the latest books (or swap yours at the library) — but all ages can also discover their own language.
Read on to learn how your child can get started with ABC Sign Language.
Talking with your child is the best communication tool you can use. Children develop language through watching and hearing, and through listening to the world around them.
Use language on how you handle toys. Connect concepts to signs.
Basic words are best to start with.
Before your child starts ABC Sign Language, practice your own dialect with your baby.
Think FUN and SIMPLE. Use kids’ words rather than donor words (like ‘TBD’), draw pictures, sing and roll your tongue.
For example, take a favorite or familiar book and add your own ABC Sign Language.
Using your own language, your children will develop a connection with their own individual voice — an important first step.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 12:17 p.m. city officials said. Calls to the address went unanswered all morning and into the afternoon.
Officials said firefighters saved a woman and a 2-year old from the fire. They attempted to rescue a 3-year-old boy but officials said firefighters couldn’t reach him in time
The woman was listed in good condition on Sunday evening. The 2-year-old boy stayed in the hospital with "moderate injuries," officials said. The Cook County Medical Examiner’s Office said the child died on Jan. 16.
The fire is still under investigation.

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 21st Asean summit in the northeastern capital, Vientiane, on September 6-8.
The Ministry of Information and Culture had publicised the rules on July 23.
Under the rules, all freelance journalists and those who have no accredited media outlets and who want to cover the summit must register with the Information and Culture Ministry at least three days prior to the event.
The ministry said media groups would be accredited and only these would be permitted to cover the summit events and dispatch reports.
Although talk of blocking the media was not mentioned directly, the ministry did not adequately explain its reasons for the regulations, causing fear that the main Lao media outlets, which are all run by the party, would be the official media sources covering the events, according to the Southeast Asia Press Alliance in a statement.

FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of a drop in input costs.
The company had reported a profit of Rs 1,310 crore during the October-December period of the previous fiscal.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Compass functions and distance alerts have become standard extensions of GPS navigation aid in some new cars since the system was invented a decade ago but the cost of installing and updating the satnav data means the technology has yet to cross into the cheaper vehicles.
Major automakers are developing Internet-linked services enabling drivers to direct friends to calibrate the air conditioning, the music or take out the trash while waiting for them.
The idea is that Internet-connected, plug-and-play units will get you home sooner, safer and less stressed as you eliminate time looking for parking spaces, deciding on which lanes are moving and potentially giving strangers driving directions as you manage your time.
To emulate the wide adoption of GPS technology in cars, the location services sector faces two tricky challenges.

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market by giving the country a bigger cut of global production.
Foxconn, the world’s largest contract electronics maker, already assembles iPhones in China, Brazil, Mexico and the United States and earlier this month said it had begun trial production of the iPhone SE in India.
Prior to this, the government has signed letters of intent with Wistron Corp, a Taiwanese joint venture with Tata Sons, and will sign the agreements after its negotiations with the other companies are completed, the officials said.
They did not identify the other companies.
HMR Ambastha, who is part of the committee evaluating proposals on behalf of the government, said Foxconn had dispatched the tender documents to prospective bidders.
Sundararajan VN, a government spokesperson, confirmed he signed the terms at a remotely held event with other executives.

Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story.
ZeedMe is a tool that allows high school students taking online college-prep classes to share trusted stories about their lives that are not captured in their college admissions paperwork.
ZeeMee's platform is free and students can share more than 30 different pre designed "ZeePledges," such as #NotOnLearnerBuses or #ThisIsMe, that other students can RSVP to if they agree with the messages, according to a statement.
Having other students post #NotOnLearnerBuses, for example, or saying "#ThisIsMe" can show a future college if the high school student has a shoulder to lean on in a challenging moment.
Having a community that understand a high schoolers' perspective can make a big difference in a students' application.

Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 170.
An additional $80 billion will be generated in 2002, so to the delight of tax auditors everywhere, the additional money comes with smaller penalty rates. The IRS can promise to send a letter asking your returns to be re-submitted if you owe more than $2,000 from your under-reported income. There are serious penalties for cheaters that intend on making the system fail, with the main goal of the tax rush to fix the system as it is, as opposed to generating more revenue. Of course, with the phasing out of dependency exemptions for children in tax-favored situations, the tax system still has a high efficiency component, considering it's subjectivity to taxpaying individuals.

(Newser) – For less than two weeks, Shelby Carter got to be what she wanted most to be—a mother. Now her friends and family in Wyoming, Ill., are honoring the sacrifice she made to save her credit card and identity. The 22-year-old gave birth to her son Phoenix in Hawaii on Aug. 14 while traveling with her husband. Although she was in labor, she wanted to have him in a hospital, the Chicago Tribune reports. Her flight home to the Chicago suburb lasted a day and a half after she stopped once in Jacksonville, Fla., to have the birth happen four weeks earlier than anticipated, the Chicago Daily Herald reports. Sadly she died before she could make it home, but the local Kiwanis Club put the word out to save her new son, and he has been adopted by one of the organization’s active members.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of poetry and quail at the potential narcissism of the poet who attempts to speak from such a circumstance. Nevertheless, it continues, the speakers continue, the words continue.        The speaker who lives on the side of a war zone has little choice but to speak. The speaker also is injured. Every time there is a gunshot near you, your heart beats fast and loudly in your ears. Each time you learn of a friend or stranger’s death, a part of you withers and dies with them. Analysis? Dissection? The word for this condition in American military circles is “symptom overload,” though it does not get harder to tolerate with time. LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, a European food safety watchdog body said on Thursday.
The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) pesticide unit said that the finding was independent of a legal battle between Bayer (BAYG.DE), which owns Monsanto, and the U.S. state of California over use of the chemical.
“In conclusion, the Panel considered that the new (GLP-study) shows no evidence of carcinogenic potential of glyphosate,” the watchdog said in a statement.
The European Commission is likely to approve the reauthorisation of the glyphosate substance for another 10 years in June, but the decision has been caught up in a dispute between the political and scientific departments.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As a Platonizing Neoplatonist, he was fully aware of the conflict between Plato and Aristotle which we have examined in the present volume [p. 144]. His energies and his abilities were devoted to a mediation between the two philosophical currents. After the break with Christianity, it must be supposed that in the beliefs of Christian theologians, the idea of the eternal de jure divino world of Plato (including the father god, the cosmos, the soul, the ideas) acquired a powerful importance. Especially of the Greek Fathers (see Holms) we have an idea that this world was cotemporal with the Christ event. (Cf. Horatius Bonus.)
The treatment of Plato in the mediaeval theological literature can be fragmentary with views which are not free from partiality and excessive emphasis. (See Holms.)

Details of the program are finally being released after Canada repeatedly promised to reveal the system before launching it Tuesday.
Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced last month that, for the first time, Canada would screen passengers by information contained in the Interpol One database — a global database of more than 20 million sets of passport and identity photographs and fingerprints collected from national identity documents, border control records and law enforcement databases.

Renting an apartment with bad credit may not be easy. Many large apartment complexes owned by corporations now require credit checks and will refuse applicants who do not meet their standards. Even if you have the income to pay for the apartment, if the owners of these property management companies don’t receive enough renters with a credit score that meets their standards, they may deny you an apartment if you have a bad credit history. However, there are examples where people with bad credit have found success in apartment rentals.
A Brief Explanation of Your Credit
Lenders grade people on a sliding scale called their FICO score that ranges from 300 to 900. In general, people with scores above 600 have a lower risk than those with scores below 600. People with scores of 620 and above may have the best odds of getting the credit they or you need. People with credit scores below 600 may have a tougher time getting an apartment, but they do have the opportunity to increase their FICO score. I am compelled to get the word out regarding a Senate bill that could adversely affect private preschools in California. The bill is labeled SB 837 or Kindergarten Readiness Act of 2014.
On the surface, SB 837 looks like a great idea. We all want "kindergarten-ready" kindergartners. But if you read the fine print, you will find that SB 837 is less about kindergarten readiness and more about one of the most devastating threats that could befall our preschool industry.
Under SB 837, the state would dictate the curriculum that all preschools are required to teach. For reference, all State preschools already have a state curriculum. Previously, it was assumed that private preschools would have the option to choose their own curriculum, which would allow each school to operate with its own philosophies and specialties.
But SB 837 dictates a state-mandated curriculum, a one-size-fits-all approach to early childhood education

A report this weekend by Axios cited documents from within the National Security Council describing the possibility — nay, inevitability — of a 5G network built and operated by the U.S. government. Officials have apparently been discussing the idea with the White House for months though nothing is definite, and the original Axios report, obtained Saturday, indicated that the idea might not even come to fruition.
An internal National Security Council memo — obtained by Axios — warned of the risks posed by the Chinese 5G network as well as the Chinese government’s close relationship with technology companies. “The United States needs a technological advantage — one that our urbanized, information-based economy demands — if we want to keep the U.S. military and economic deterrents effective amid a potential tit-for-tat,” the memo stated. According to Axios, the memo also noted that the project’s goal is to make the 5G network as ubiquitous as possible, making the “impossibility” of patching the network a motivator for the project.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches the desired recipient at all.
First, the letter’s addressee receives the letter through the gatekeeper responsible for verifying who the letter is for. Accordingly, you don’t have discretion with how you address a letter once you are sure the letter is going to the proper person. First impressions count, though. Make sure that the letter is legible, or else it may be refused or sent back to you.
How to Write a Simple Business Envelope Address
Write the correct corporation name and type it out exactly as it appears on the company’s letterhead and the “To Whom It May Concern” letter itself. If the corporation submits a letter with a letterhead or other document with its address or contact information on it when you download it from the Internet, you can find the corporation’s contact information and office location on the letter.

Metaphysics special: Do we have free will?
“DID I really just decide to have fish and chips for lunch?” Humans have been wrestling with such questions for millennia. Maybe not about the fish and chips — although there are philosophical questions around the consumption of anchovies — but with the existence of free will.
If people didn’t have free will, how could they be held accountable for their actions? Take prospective jurors out of the equation, as well as those tasked with categorizing possible jokes made by bots in AI, and the question becomes whether the fundamental nature of human decision-making is pre-determined or not.
This skepticism has almost always existed. “Ever since the world began people have been thinking about how fundamental choice is and the roles that we play in the things that happen in the world,” said Sam Camras, although the idea that our fate is determined by factors largely out of our control — gods, fate, astrology — has mingled through. Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat lung and throat infections such as pneumonia and tonsillitis. It can also treat skin and soft tissue infections, such as cellulitis and wound infections. It can also be used to prevent tonsillitis in people with rheumatic heart disease.
Each yellow, round, flat-faced, bevelled-edge tablet, debossed with "NC192" on one side and "100" on the other contains 100 mg of clarithromycin. Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, leading to a more acidic ocean with elevated carbon dioxide.
As a result, shell-producing organisms, including plankton and smaller creatures ingested by fish, are less active compared to preindustrial times, according to a new study by Penn State researchers published in Deep Sea Research II: Topical Studies in Oceanography late last month.
This phenomenon is causing drastic effects on plankton population size in ocean regions known as the "twilight zone," situated in a subsurface zone below the ocean sunlight limit, but above the ocean's twilight zone where deep-water fish feed.
"The computer modeling revealed a strong interplay between increased acidification and reduced fertilization rates, producing a silent winter.” said Marie-Pierre Jeannotte, Associate Professor of Biology.

PROFESSOR Peter Higgs of Edinburgh University may now stand as a scientific legend alongside the likes of Newton, Oppenheimer and Einstein.
But the Noble laureate-in-waiting is far from the arbiter-like figure one might expect.
Higgs’s reportedly cool demeanour is underwritten by a fight or flight response he inherited from a family of military men.
HIGGS has two brothers – Geoffrey and Brinsley – and one sister, also named Brinsley – with whom he maintains a strong relationship.
Like his siblings, Higgs, 94, has lived a life even more remarkable than his own mathematical achievements.
For a country man from north Leeds, the scientist has jetted all over the world and has the accents to prove it.
He has survived a World War Two stint, 10 years studying physics in Cambridge, happily married twice and a baffling trip to a Bilderberg conference – and lived a healthy 70 years longer than Homer Simpson.

Surely some bright (or at least, gullible) kid sitting in front of the bathroom mirror with his parents’ copy of Amazing World of Super-Heroes devoured Double-Bubble gum and crumpled up the ad, then peered into the black tube for a fuzzy image.
Researchers at the Georgia Institute of Technology and the Singapore University of Technology and Design recently took on a similar project, but as with all research projects, there is no time for frivolity.
A typical smartphone camera reveals an image with structure and detail, whether that detail is internal or on the surface. Such basic optical techniques are the foundation for the proposed polymer-coated smartphone with add-on optics to extend the camera’s resolution to the nanoscale.

London: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would not be derailed from leaving the European Union (EU) by a no confidence vote in her and instead work with other parties to continue Brexit negotiations.
Downing Street said she had an invitation from the European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker to meet him in Brussels after lawmakers rejected five successive pieces of Brexit legislation on Saturday.

Labour also ramped up no confidence calls with a letter signed by 179 of its lawmakers backing a challenge to May, as the party judged it has the numbers in Parliament to bring her down.

The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.
AFHSD is primarily the historical research and book writing arm of Air Force, but also performs a variety of other efforts that ensure the rich history of the Air Force lives on.
AFHSD is home to three separate research teams with the task of supporting Association of Histories Departments (AHDP) demands and other tasks.
AFHSD’s archivist maintains, manages and provides access to the AFHSD archives located in the Air Force tradecraft and flights records room.
AFHSD contracts with independent archaeologists to support the Air Force Archaeological Program and artifact collection; produces the annual Air Force socio-cultural catalog.

Tributes have been paid to young Teesside mum Laura Hodgson who has lost her fight for life.
Laura, from Billingham , was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer last year.
The mum of a one-year-old had previously battled the disease on a week-to-week basis after reaching remission the first time she was diagnosed.
But she relapsed a year after the last surgery, after being told the cancer had returned in her lymph nodes just below her clavicle.
Her first brush with the killer disease was a chance meeting. As she went to get a coffee at her work canteen in Billingham in October, Laura attended the KICs work canteen with colleagues. As she took a seat, a female member of her team approached her and gave her a big hug.

Many users have been hoodwinked into forwarding an inaccurate warning about the spread of non-existent malware that claims a girl committed suicide because of it.

Facebook users should be on the alert for a new malware hoax making the rounds on the popular social network.

In actuality, the wife of one of the hackers behind the While You Were Away scam has been infiltrating Facebook hacking communities and injecting a hoax Facebook link into the conversations, pretending she’s a young woman in a bad position, according to World Security Inc. Edinburgh's Hogmanay kicks off very soon - here's everything you need to know about the end of year celebration.
When and where does the Torchlight Procession take place?
In recent years the Torchlight Procession has been the Saturday before New Year's Eve (which is a Monday), so if you've seen it take place on the Sunday, don't worry you weren't late for the party.
In fact, the torch-wielding celebrators gather in east Princes Street near the Royal Mile around six o'clock just before making their way to George Square (and will continue on until well after midnight), so you don't have to stick around to see the whole procession, though we're sure everyone can find a canny way to make it a reason to sit outdoors into the late hours.
We'll be with you from the moment the torches are lit and you can relive the Ferryboat Kelpie's journey down the road to the Waterfront with one of our choirs performing popular Scottish folk tunes.

Dietrich Bonhoeffer has always been one of my great heroes of the faith. Such appreciation, of course, hardly makes me distinct. Bonhoeffer, the German pastor-theologian who opposed the Nazis and eventually faced the execution order, is one of the most widely revered men of the 20th century. For the church, he represents a forerunner of the theologians who so compellingly nuanced the theology of liberation in the 1970s and 1980s and an antagonist of the church fathers who have become booksellers and theologians and medical missionaries; and for the academy, he represents a universal democrat more than tainted by identity group politics or the secular precepts of self-fulfillment or the spirit of history, a man to whom we are all indebted. God bless Dietrich. He remains a hero, but I continue to wonder how my orientation toward him affects my imagining of the argument of this book.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Abdul Latif, a columnist for the luxury borders outdoor magazine Information Age, was taken into custody after publishing a book online calling for the replacement of decades-old subsidy policies.
His wife, Amira Abdul Latif, who is also the author's lawyer, told Reuters he had been jailed for at least three years in a security case in the past and jailed for short periods twice in recent months on the charge of publishing false news. Lawyer Abdul Latif described the arrest as a “joke”.
Another author in the same case, Atef al-Khateib, was jailed by a military court for three months earlier this month on the same security charge.

LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
Ash from the Medesar coal-fired plant near Genoa, Italy, will dock on 11 August. An expected output increase of 60,000-70,000 tonnes of ash a day is anticipated.
Eni’s coal-fired Medesar plant was the world's first project to use boilers with flue gas conditioning system (FGD). The boilers use emissions control equipment to compensate for the ash from the burnt coal.
Work performed during the August maintenance period also includes the testing of the Medesar’s boilers with Pfister burners, the SOFC (solid oxide fuel cell) trial facility, the construction of a new direct ash concentrator and homogenization in dry condition.
Spending for these projects total €550m ($628m) up to the end of 2013.

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should demonstrate that you know the company and what you can offer. Here are seven effective ways to prepare for an interview question like this.
Employers want to know motivated applicants will contribute to the success of the organization. Gather information about the company during your interview preparation. Find out the company mission statement, along with its objectives, goals, and overall vision. Describe how you can develop as a professional and contribute to the achievement of the company's objectives.
Hiring managers want successful candidates who can think outside the box and solve problems. Describe how your skills have enabled you to solve problems in the past. This is also a chance to highlight your unique perspective and how it can impact the job you are applying for.
Many job seekers struggle when it comes to this type of question: what can you do to make us better? But don’t just regurgitate your employment objectives during the interview: discuss how

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California-based specialty pharma company's headcount from 49 to 31 -- shriveled to a skeleton staff of eight from the company's opening with more than 100 workers in late 2006.
Aduro is sponsoring just one clinical study now. The company, which did $10 million in sales during the past 18 months, said the move is intended to streamline operations as it seeks new funding to continue development of its three drug candidates.
Now in Phase I clinical trials are the plasmablastic lymphoma drug ADU-741 and the HIV therapy ADU-742. Clinical trials of another drug leading the roughly $60 million NIH-funded human microbiome study are expected to start later this year.

BANGKOK – The preliminary rites of the coronation of the new King Vajiralongkorn of Thailand, who ascended to the throne in October 2017 after the death of his father King Bhumibol Adulyadej, are to start June 7 with entertainment in the evening and a grand feast the next day.
State media reported, citing a spokesman for the new king, that the nine-day preliminary celebrations will cancel official engagements for government ministers so that the 65-year-old king can attend the feasts.
It is his first official occasion as a monarch ending 70 years of Chakri Dynasty rule.
The Royal Household Bureau said the preliminary feasts would mark the coronation and celebrate the late King Bhumibol’s birthday on December 5.
The official coronation, according to the Bangkok Post, will start October 4 with a three-day ceremony called the Royal Ploughing Ceremony held at the royal palace.

Russia is not in talks with Syria about supplying the Assad regime with its S-300 advanced air defense system and does not think they are needed, Vladimir Kozhin, an aide to Russian President Vladimir Putin on military - industrial complex, told the TASS news agency on Wednesday.
Moscow already has a "good military partnership" with the region's economy, so it is diverting its resources to improving the mechanisms of the relationship, Kozhin added.
Kozhin in an interview with TASS said that the S-300 air defense system did not play a major role in either geopolitics or consequences of the currently ongoing conflict in Syria. "Russia and Iran are strong weapons partners, which ensures the good state of security in the region," he explained.
"We understand that today the military situation in the region has largely subsided. Therefore, there is no demand for the S-300 missile system," Kozhin said of the advanced air defense system, known also as S-300VM or Antey-2500.

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car approval process is one of the Commission's so-called "college" powers that allow the vice-presidents of the executive, plus the transport commissioner, to object to EU laws if they are feared to cause legal incoherence.
Portugal election: European Socialists emerge as winners
On the plus side, the idea allows them to force national governments to stick to the letter of the law when applying existing legislation in a more concrete, though often slower, fashion.
It is also supposed to preclude national governments making a rule one way some of the time and a different rule at others, providing a check on how stringent existing rules are applied.
The college power secured some victories in excessive pesticide use and capping executives' "golden parachutes", but no in the automotive world where the college has not formally overruled national governments once.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-to-New York City train hit the construction equipment around 2 a.m. outside the ductwork just east of the Belmont-Waverly area, said Lisa DeJaco, a spokeswoman for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, which owns the subway line.
The train rolled on the street for a couple of blocks after the crash and no injuries were reported among the 61 passengers on the eight-car train.
The train later returned to Boston and the other passengers boarded another train for their destinations.
The employee was found behind a board and suffering the heart attack in a tunnel, said Leo Melia, a spokesman for the Boston Transit. The worker was taken to a Baystate Medical Center in Springfield with cause of death pending.
The contractor was able to move the train using cranes after the impact, according to DeJaco of the MBTA.

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 30 to 9 margin late Thursday, sending the proposal to the governor for his consideration.
Leaders of the state House and Senate have already committed to crafting a bill with the governor, Senate President Pro Tem Jerry Sonnenberg and Democratic House Leader Dickey Lee Hicks said at a news conference Friday morning.
“The intent is for us to have a system for medical marijuana to be taxed properly, just as any other business does today,” Sonnenberg said.
As Colorado law currently stands, marijuana sellers are allowed to accept only cash. While state law does allow medical marijuana businesses to take credit cards for payment, it can only be done via a system in which a journalist or other barter participant directly transact with a marijuana provider and watch the deal go down.

Credit cards have caused financial pain for millions of consumers. It's easy to run up a balance, but as too many people find out the hard way, trying to get out from under a pile of debt can be just as difficult. Learning how to get out of debt (or not acquiring it in the first place), should be a goal for every one of us. Here are a few tips on how to deal with credit cards if you want to avoid them.
1. Shop with cash
The excitement of new objects, clothes, gift certificates, lifestyle changes...we want it all, then we get it all. Once we get everything we've wanted, it's all already paid for. Until the credit card bill arrives, that is. Those bills always feel like an alien creature as you take it out of the mailbox. Once your enjoyment moment is over, look at the entire bill as if it were cash and assess whether you have the cash to cover it. If not, don't buy it with the credit card.

Black Panther‘s box office dominance continues to soar with the latest batch of release update figures, which arrive as the superhero movie eclipsed Titanic to become the third highest-grossing film of all time.
Earlier this month, the blockbuster became the top grossing opening weekend film yet in all-time box office history with a US$201.8m in ticket sales, and it’s thanks to the powerful global numbers that have seen its total worldwide takings now pass $1.1bn ($1.4bn).
It means the Ryan Coogler-directed film has moved up the rankings to match a feat achieved only by the likes of James Cameron’s Gravity and Avatar and its sequel Titanic (although the latter has still managed a higher final worldwide tally).

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden in December 1898.
It was discovered a few months ago on a beach on Kampen in the Netherlands - more than 5,000km (3,100 miles) from the North Sea.
The letter inside was never picked up - and the call ends with the words "Here's wishing all good luck".
A present belonging to Heinrich van der Molen
It was recently cleaned and restored by experts from the American Association for Bomb Scooby and the World Wide Marine Society.
The letter was located by a group of friends - including the grandson of the 12-year-old who scratched it out 108 years ago.
The well-preserved letter was distributed by a group of German children as part of a competition to find a Christmas present for an orphaned girl in Meppel.

Two officers of a company that operates three Manhattan hotels were indicted yesterday in a scheme to help homeless people fraudulently obtain welfare checks and split the money with the hotels.
District Attorney Robert S. Johnson said that the officers and 10 other defendants conspired to cash up to 1000 checks every month. A security flaw in the welfare system made it easy for some people to receive money intended for distribution to people for whom the money had been intended.
Typically, poor people get $50 cash payments and tax refunds that are issued four times a year.
The indictment alleges that the security flaw has existed at least since 1976, when the system was introduced in the Northeast to give the poor cash bonuses.
Those participating in the welfare fraud scheme, Mr. Johnson said yesterday, got the Bronx welfare-superiors. They then knew who had not turned in their applications and where to get the checks easily cashed. Even the signatures weren't a barrier.

“We have seen a marked uptick in shopping and flights from India to Europe in the last two years alone and this sets the perfect stage for the high luxury, all-inclusive travel experience of The B servicing the areas so much needed.”

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies own their own servers, many smaller providers only have a limited number of servers to rent server space to clients. This means they rent interior server space to people looking for web hosting services.
People can save a substantial amount of money when purchasing web servers directly from a large site rather than going through a reseller as a middleman. However, some find it harder to deal with a large company directly, and prefer to have a reseller act as the intermediary.
Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
The profit margin on reseller hosting is around $40 profit per server, according to Certainly Web Solutions, a reseller hosting company. This is the company's estimated profit rate for server refreshes. The profit depends on what the cannibalization rate of a server actually is. FAIRVIEW, W.Va (WDTV) - Several of you in Fairview have reached out to 5 News over the last few days saying the water is discolored and dirty.
Some said it's a brownish-red color.
The Russell County Water and Sewer Authority sent us aeration and sediment samples and a letter explaining what the samples show.
We talked with a Professor at WVU College of Engineering and Mineral Resources, reviewed the samples, and compared the results to the sample we sent to the air quality authority to get a better idea of what the water looks like.
Authorities said surface water samples taken from the water tower near Sick Creek are breaking down Tannic Acid. It's similar to an iron molecules in the surface water that's causing a brown-red color to the water.
That being said... your water is safe.
Authority assures you it meets all criteria and standards of the EPA.
If the smell clean water protocol is followed properly Sick Creek water is considered safe.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Mortality Rate – or the number of babies who do not survive the first 28 days after birth – decreased from 6.67 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2000 to 5.16 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2010, a 23% reduction.
But that improvement levled out in the last few years with a six-year average of 5.20 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in the decade from 2000 to 2009 followed by a 5.23 rate from 2010 to 2013. Last year’s rate was 5.29 per 1,000 live births.

The real estate rental market is a highly localized, relationship-based industry driven largely by individuals living and working in their own cities, causing many to acknowledge its ongoing infancy.
Having undergone a period of consolidation during the housing crisis, more and more organizations are now focusing primarily on the rental side, providing less capital and more operational know-how, and taking advantage of a mature platform to create a playbook of success.
Anthony Ross, CEO of ApartmentSearch, recently wrote a post surveying the explosive growth of the rental market in the U.S. and explaining how the “level of scale to profitability is more a function of hours”.
Even more importantly, the competition is on the rise in this segment – specifically because it is still an untapped avenue for potential real estate investors.
The optimal model is the one where a REIT and a collaborative network of renters and renters come together as a united front to design an offensive plan for the long-term success of the company.

Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy from the sun. Formed 4.6 billion years ago during the Big Bang, Earth’s crust—which gives us land and oceans (and the continents also called crust by geologists)—is a combination of magma, molten rock, and solid rock pieces.
As Earth crust generates some thermal energy, some is stored in the mantle, which is cooler than the crust yet hotter than the core. Materials in the mantle heat up as layers beneath them cool; these are carried away to the surface and form volcanoes and earthquakes.
Thermal energy of the mantle is derived mainly from radioactive decay in early primitive materials when the planetÃ¢’s background radiation was hotter, leaving a weakly heat generating remnant at the mantle. Since the steam engine is fueled by coal, in the Big Bang, a massive nuclear event formed a large amount of helium.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as fibroblasts appear to work together to send a signal to the micro-environment around a cell to limit the growth or damage from genetic changes to the DNA.
The discovery — made using live fur-coated adult elephants, excised kidney and heart cells from a deceased elephant, and engineered human skin fibroblast cells — could help humans with cancer use drugs to pre-emptively knock the disease out.
DNA has the potential to get damaged by multiple factors — including natural aging processes, chemical toxins, infectious organisms, radiation, and cellular processes during wound healing and stress.
After DNA becomes fragmented or part of it deforms into the shape known as an inverted repeat, whole groups of DNA-repairing proteins called PARPs square up, collecting justice ready to the cell to carry out PARP-driven repair.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the University of California, Los Angeles, examined the impact of yoga on eight people with high anxiety — an average of 7 on the Mental Health Inventory scale. The yoga poses (such as child pose and trikonasana) were chosen according to the tradition and the poses that made participants feel the least anxious. The twice-weekly 60-minute sessions also involved meditation (descending the breath Counts, Cycle of the Seasons) and a ritual to center into the heart (Anahata Kriya). Researchers put the participants into two groups and provided one with a pacay (formerly Calliandra calothyrcus), a medicinal plant also known by the name Chilean pepper tree, to fairly evaluate the effectiveness of the yoga treatment group’s uplifted experience of self and the poses themselves.

New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces took a closer look at the emissions reductions timelines included in new five-year plans published by the so-called ‘Big 22’ companies – Banks (ANZ, NAB, Westpac and Commonwealth Bank of Australia), miners (BHP, Rio, Whitehaven, Woodside), energy (AGL Energy, Santos, Origin), materials (Orica) and infrastructure (Ausgrid).
“Climate change is the greatest market failure in history and the only way to insure against these risks is to immediately transition to a clean energy future,” Market Forces director Julien Gauthier said in a statement.
“These companies are planning for the worst even as the tide is turning globally, with large corporations across the world looking to the Paris agreement to navigate the new energy transition.”

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by Sir Hugh AC, reached the sea ice edge. Early charts are archaic views of the continent with the single treatment of the ice which covers much of the North. The data are collected and made available by Naval Research Laboratory(NRL) through the Center for Coastal Physical Oceanography(CCPO). Funding for SYNOPSIS and other acronyms refers to National Oceanographic Partnership Program (NOPP).

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemicals at a time when they cost more and have become a hot issue. And using compost as mulch is one of the time-tested, no-brainer ways to get your yard to look its best immediately.
One of the needs most commonly neglected in the spirit of saving time and money is getting our beds ready for spring.
After a long Alberta winter, a thorough clean-up is required as those old leaves don't have much life left in them.

Some history
Thomas Jefferson wrote about Revere's ride to the Massachusetts colonists resistance, being the inspiration for the town meeting he had attended a week earlier.
George Gile wrote it was the subject of election day orations – including one by Daniel Webster.
John Quincy Adams wrote about it in letters to his adopted American grandfather, Abigal Adams, wife of the seventh president.
History professor Louis S. Gerry wrote about it in a book on the subject of the ride titled, Midnight Ride of Paul Revere .

In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control announcing an end to the program. Regulators said it was deceptive to call a distillery and order a mixed drink when such business have been forced by law to resume selling spirits straight up or on the rocks.
"We essentially began regulating like a large mass-producing distillery with people that are unique and have a personal touch that is not the same at the big guys, the Williams SONOMAS and the Jack Daniel's," board member Loyd Wray said.
The Alaska Distillers Association complained to the board chair, Cathy Endres, about a negative tone in meetings with the board and were told the agency is considering a ban by June.
"This is not more than trying to be fair," Endres said.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter Maya.
Karnow's acclaimed work on Vietnam, "Very Long War," won a National Book Award in the hybrid category more than 30 years ago.
Meticulously researched, the book drew on foreign news reports, U.S. and North Vietnamese military documents, a stream of oral accounts — including some by Karnow's own military aide in Vietnam — and the writer's own observations.
Published in 1983, the book — which conservative organizations derided as "mercilessly anti-American" — disturbed some veterans. Karnow later wrote that the book was "eye-opening" and that it did "not intend to denigrate the American fighting men," but rather to describe the war in a

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify the potential impact of the options they have with a task. The diagram shows the consequences of a decision – the probability of the decisions' outcomes, while the costs are mapped as a branch that leads to a final decision. A well-constructed decision tree allows a more thorough decision on a business’s strategy.
A decision tree can be referenced to assess important investment decisions, to evaluate the viability of a project, to estimate a mortgage payment or other financial decision, or to do a simple cost and return analysis of the programs that you are developing. A well-developed decision tree should show the cost of each part of it by using the simple cost formula.
Let’s take a simple example to show how to build a decision tree in a single step:

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered towards the mine around noon (0700 GMT) on Saturday after heavy rainfall, according to Sama Le Min Min, a local official.
At least a dozen people are feared buried – including a Jackson Mayit, a photographer caught in the landslide with his brother, Kham Thar Myint Linn.
Yangbay Lawu, 65, ran the jade mine with Myanmar’s military, according to a police statement on Saturday.
Officials have not identified the mine owner in media reports.
Most of the area is controlled by the armed forces, according to Yangbay Lawu’s nephew, Win Thu.
“We are very sad, and have tried all our best, with more than 80 rescue workers, but have so far not found a single human body,” he said in Sunday.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp.
Due to limitations with the technology, though, the clone stamp had to be applied to an image that you had obviously already imported, which introduced a fair amount of unnecessary steps into the process of editing. Adobe fixed this with the introduction of a content-aware tool that only required you to paint a brushstroke into a layer, and automatically applied the aforementioned technique there.
These three tools have a similar history. Like the devoted clone stamp, there exists a group of Lightroom users who have been content with their tried-and (true third party plug-ins). This makes sense; they have been honed over the course of years by some very creative people with a ton of real-world experience. Third-party plug-ins can be been the difference between working well with Lightroom’s PTGui Surface Detect tool and struggling with it.

Taipei, July 18 (CNA) U.S.-based search engine giant Google on Wednesday launched a new Google Maps service for motorbike riders in Taiwan that will help them plan their routes and calculate their costs.
"These motorbike users no longer have to worry about petrol stations along their route or parking facilities near tourist sites," Google Taiwan Marketing Indonesia Resident Director Chen Wen-ling (陳文玲) said in Taipei.
The new Google Maps application allows motorbike riders to easily search for gasoline stations, helmet locker rooms, parking facilities, police stations, and treatment centers along their proposed routes with one click, she said.
Users can also calculate the costs incurred throughout their journeys to access data regarding petrol prices, highway tolls, helmet fees, and treatment rates.
"Many drivers on Google Maps get stranded along their routes due to traffic jam or other reasons. We hope these new features of Google Maps go a long way to make them safer, more efficient, and easier," she said.

The Waste Land as an iPad app demonstrates how we might re-imagine the book, but it also illustrates how editorial choices can limit value.
The Guardian recently documented a June trek of 25 people through T. S. Eliot’s famous poem, The Waste Land, on the App Store under the category ‘poems’ (see screenshot below).
Given the drastic shift in how consumers now receive media, this seems like a perfect microcosm of how the media world might more generously define the concept of ‘story.’
iPad editions are, by definition, editable. We as readers can draw, take notes (or snap photos); share passages or collections widely with the touch of a screen. A ‘story’ like Eliot’s can be experienced by any person who chooses to take the time – not just the teleorgraphic brigade who can fund the latest innovations in publishing.

Q. I have an annuity worth about $70,000. I am retired and I need the money. They say I would get $125 a month for 10 years. This isn't enough. Can you recommend a plan that gives more? - Beverly
A. Annual income may have decreased more than your annuity benefit. This usually occurs when the average lifespan of the insured (like mine) exceeds the average duration of the plan. Because of the length of your plan, 10 years, the hundreds of policies in the insurance company's records show a lower average lifespan.
Here's the action: Write to the company and request a statement showing your deferred income plan's mortality! Tell them you want to know the life expectancy that gives the highest average monthly annuity amount at the age of retirement. Be sure to mention your age!

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot tempers.
A study published earlier this year by the same research group discovered a strong link between so-called "warm grandmothers" — women with more positive maternal relationship with their granddaughters — and less fighting and teasing among those younger girls.
Now a new paper published earlier this year in the journal Menopause, following up on that 2009 study, examined the connection between grandmothers and granddaughter aggression.
For the study, the researchers had 60 pairs of women — grandmothers and daughters — complete a survey on aggression in the granddaughter group. In addition, 30 granddaughters completed the study, submitting a questionnaire about the gender-role attitudes of their grandmothers.

Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive. The company recently completed its goals for the initial Stinger project, on which it began work in 2011. The company is working with the community so other users can take advantage of the new work and discuss how to help Hive scale for more applications.
Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive.
Stinger was first developed so applications could use the entire Hadoop platform to get more processing power and the computational capabilities of Apache Hadoop’s YARN technology. It added memory-optimized execution to allow micromapping technologies to have more granular control over how much resources they managed themselves.
Hortonworks took responsibility to get YARN in GA late last year in the 2.x series that shook the Hadoop ecosystem when the project’s leaders -- Pivotal and Hortonworks -- announced they would go their separate ways.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just one of the many benefits of buying a commercial application.
But the small- and midsize-business (SMB) world is traditionally wonderfully heterogeneous, with vendors often offering a handful of legacy applications, all integrated with a wide array of others without deep disclosure of how the main application actually works. Its source code tends to be viewed as the Holy Grail of ERP vendors to be kept in a vault at the vendor's headquarters.
A few other applications, traditionally made available only to large enterprises with a 100-employee, $100 million GDP threshold, are looking at expanding to more SMB users.
Then, you have pure open-source vendors, such as OpenNetware, Opentaps and Compiere.
The largest vendors have also traditionally advised users to purchase only commercial software.

The statue of Robert the Bruce at The Battle of Bannockburn Centre. PIC: Michael Gillen/Falkirk Herald.
There is possibly no other figure in Scottish history greater worshipped than Robert the Bruce.
Pardoned by the Pope immediately after his return to the Scottish throne in 1329, King Robert is celebrated across the country with tales of valour and personal sacrifice from battles as far apart as Bannockburn (June 1314) and his eventual independence from England.
But away from the melee of warfare he also helped to reshape Scotland – not least with the government he set up in Edinburgh Castle.
In 1316, the Treaty of Northampton marked an acceptance by the English crown that the Bruce dynasty was once again the governing family of Scotland.
Along with a renewed trademark vigour, the king would use the peace to bring order to a country plagued by factional division.

On October 30, a major new report on the impact of Marcellus Shale gas development on water resources will be issued. Water Resource Reporting and Water Footprint from Marcellus Shale Development in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, prepared by Butler (WV) County Public Works Director, Amanda Watson, PhD, and Sustainable Water Resource Management specialist Aaron Jacobs, PhD, exposes the environmental shortcomings of the boom. Among the startling conclusions are:
1. Water withdrawal rates over the past three years are on par with water use patterns during the height of World War II-level steel production and are associated with the highest rate of stream degradation and aquatic life mortality in the last 30 years.
2. Current water discharges from unconventional wells are at least double the rate of a typical well producing 30 barrels a day of oil and gas.
3. Water is withdrawn rapidly while treatment facilities are not constructed at the same rate.
4. There is no monitoring of other water resources, and the potential exists for degrading additional resources.

Sunday will be the 42nd annual Earth Day celebration. Here are a few things to know about the history of the event.
President Jimmy Carter established the first Earth Day, an observance to support environmental protection, on April 22, 1970. Millions of Americans participated.
Twenty million people — the largest group gathered in a human event — attended an Earth Day rally on the Washington Monument monument grounds in 1990, according to the book “Earth Day: The First 20 Years.”
More than 500,000 people participated in Earth Day celebrations in Switzerland in 1990.
We keep track of the planet's health with a growing collection of spaceships.

The security vendor Avast has received a $100m investment from private equity firm Summit Partners, in exchange for a minority stake in the company.
Avast chief executive Vince Steckler described the move as a “significant” vote of confidence in the firm’s future success. “With plenty more room to offer hardware, software and services-driven antivirus protection in the consumer security and privacy space, our plan will intensify after the cash sum is at work in the company in increasing R&D and other areas,” Steckler said.
According to Steckler, the company also hopes to expand into the business security space (which is currently smaller than the consumer security sector).
Launched in the late 1980s, the Czech-based Avast provides security software and is one of the largest vendors of security products in the world. Its corporate customers include firms such as Acer, Fujitsu-Siemens and Bell Canada.
According to Steckler, the cash infusion will see the company create more than 2000 jobs over the next three years.
