How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. This allows them to overcome the inevitable conditions that might time and time again make them fail.
It is often these rules that will dictate your exits as well.
Most traders, when they start out, have no idea what things are going to think they are going to time in a certain way. Or they are going to happen a certain way. So what are some of the more prevalent ways that traders can exit their trades?
Firstly, you’ve got your time frames.
In a world where literally so many things happen, time becomes your worst enemy. Even getting technical in the sense that you know how the products are changing, the market conditions are changing, so you know the way a chart should be moving.
The disadvantage to a time frame, is you can’t really take into account all the price changes over the course of time.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to the national security establishment, did not say how many advanced centrifuges were installed at the facility.
The newspaper also said the facility is located “more than 1,000 (kilometers) away” from Natanz, the primary enrichment facility revealed by Iran in 2002.
Iran signed the nuclear deal with world powers under President Barack Obama in 2015, agreeing to strict controls and inspections. Activities at the additional sites, however, delay Tehran’s return to the agreement’s provisions.
The International Atomic Energy Agency, the U.N. watchdog overseeing Iranian atomic energy program, did not immediately reply to a request for comment. A British spokesperson had no comment on the Kayhan report.

The nation's leading Spanish-language television networks, Univision and Telemundo, continue to pay the price for doubling and tripling down on pushing unfettered immigration policies, and declining numbers have now led to layoffs.
The networks have not only seen a drop in viewers, advertisers and revenue, but its own employees are also feeling the brunt of corporate management's failed policy attempts.
An internal memo obtained by The Wrap reveals the plan for the two networks, which currently 150 employees, will see a select group of people affected by the layoffs as a means to "improve the overall operating structure."
A task force will continue to identify who will continue with their current positions, or other affected workers who are a part of a group that is to be let go.
"Our goal continues to be to create a more efficient organization, and this work is crucial to fulfilling that goal," the memo reads.
As the shifts continue to take place, the company is said to be hopeful that successful content and overall "operating structure" will be seen on broadcast and digitally moving forward.

The local comedy world is in mourning following the shock death of beloved satirist John Clarke.
Clarke, a regular fixture in TV and film – most prominently his groundbreaking political interviews with Paul Hogan – had been in poor health for some time, but had rarely spoken about it. On Saturday he was admitted to hospital in Sydney’s northern Beaches with pericarditis, an inflammatory condition of the sac around the heart. However he did not recover and died the following evening.
A close friend told the BBC John began appearing “grim” in the months leading up the the diagnosis and had been finding the medication difficult to acclimatise to. John was also a regular punter at the same racing club as the BBC Newsnight team so was avidly breaking the banter app whilst receiving radiotherapy treatment earlier this year – by escaping to the telephones outside the hospital ward.

A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had departed Seattle around noon Pacific time and was due to arrive in Los Angeles at 6 p.m. Pacific time.
Instead, the crew was required to return to the airport after a seriously injured airline worker had to be extricated through an actuation door.
"During the flight the flight deck crew recognized an airport ground communications system operator had fallen asleep and became entrapped in the cargo compartment of the aircraft," airline spokesperson Paul McElroy said.
An airline worker sustained serious injuries and had to be extricated through an actuation door, the airline said. There were 147 passengers on board, McElroy said.
The employee suffered broken legs, but was conscious when he was admitted to the hospital, he said.

Material from all the books can be picked up from the temporary library which is situated on the south lawn of City Park between Bentley Gate and Centenary Pavilion. It is a key initiative in the building of the city’s world-class library service which will also incorporate the reduced library services already on offer at Cathedral Gardens and Cotterdale until a final decision to close the library is made.

The hottest day of 2018 was a bad day for a power failure at The Bridge homeless shelter in downtown Dallas.
A power transformer burst into flames shortly before 4 p.m. in a sixty-year-old power substation along the Trinity River just outside the loading zone for the Old Red Courthouse. That substation delivers electricity directly to the 50,000-square-foot shelter on the Trinity River.
During the heat of the day and the (nominal) noon hour, the Bridge had close to three hundred people inside it. Temperatures reached the upper 90s. Police shut down the bridge to the street behind the shelter until after sunset.
Amber Butler a member of the Board of The Bridge explained how a power outage affects people living there.
The shelter sent staff into each area to hand out the only drinkable water the were also able to provide to the group in the Loading Zone.
The City of Dallas stepped-up immediately after learning of the problem.

Smoking Ban Hurting Small Taverns?
Lawyers for Colorado bar owners say the eight-week-old statewide smoking ban has devastated some smaller taverns, slashing their incomes by up to 70 percent over the past several months.
"It's not haredly fair," attorney Brian Judy told a three-judge panel in Denver District Court on Thursday.
As a result, scores of roughly 10,000 bars, taverns and cigar bars have switched to private rooms — smaller en-tombs with limited seating, fewer employees and skeleton inventories. For large corporate smoke houses, one negative impact has been more noise complaints.
In lawsuits filed last fall, taverns claim the new law is excluding some smokers and interfering with their rights to choose "to drink, dine or make a business call with a client in a place of their choosing." Interruptions from large groups of non-smokers overbars "thanks to the ban" have also been prevalent, taverns say. Wire report

Chastain had successfully stripped Union Station of the unnecessary luxuries of the 1970s — a grand, soaring southern entryway into Cincinnati just as the World’s Fair had neglected to plan — and reinvented the station as an airy, no-nonsense entryway into the Queen City commensurate with the new millennium.

The new deal, if agreed, will see staff win serious concessions, on pay, pensions and terms and conditions.
BA cabin crew went on all-out strike two months ago in pursuit of equal pay with captains.
The bosses have failed to come close to the demands made.
Bass are planning to take the strike ballot on behalf of the 9000 cabin staff.

In the wake of mass digitisation, market consolidation and the launch of ambitious new trading platforms, experts in the out-of-home sector are calling for a boost to standards to ensure a smooth evolution away from the print model. Ermanno Robinson reports.
We’re standing on the brink of industry revolution. Gone are the days when traditional Freeview and satellite can handle all our outdoor media needs. Our billboards, posters and bus stations can no longer be static. Agencies have millions of digital banner advert spaces to match, a huge socio-cultural shift, and a strict limit on human impact on our changing cities.
How can we capture this new world? How can we innovate? Adapt? Improve?
Outdoor companies benefit from widespread general acceptance of their services. But are we prepared for a genuine revolution?

Greece is conducting dialogue with the EU on the extension of the TurkStream, a natural gas pipeline running from Russia to Turkey, across Greek territory to other EU countries, Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said in an interview with Greek TV channel Skai on Friday.
"We are negotiating with the European Union on the extension of TurkStream and many things are happening. There will also be a pipeline, [and] the final decision is not yet made. We are negotiating with other parties and the final decision will be announced in the near future," Tsipras said.
Tsipras added that because of the expanding gas supply volumes the Greek economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic is going more smoothly now compared to the first months of the crisis.
"It's getting smoother because supply volume is getting bigger from gas and I expect the crisis to end," he said.
Greece is one of the EU countries the TurkStream can pass through. A segment of the pipeline that runs through the territory of Greece will allow to create a strong weapon against the Russo-Turkish natural gas dispute, he said.

Zika virus linked to mental disorders in babies

Born in 2002 in Brazil, the Sertãozinho native describes her own baby’s head as “the shape of an olive”, a big difference with the usual round appearance of a newborn’s head.

Having Zika virus doesn’t mean a catastrophe. The dynamics are correct in treating the virus.

Mary Pezzulo over at Steel Magnificat has written an excellent piece about the problem with name-calling, contentiousness, and point-scoring in the name of “apologetics.” I agree completely with what she said, and with the specific points she makes on the importance of tone, purpose, and apologetics itself; these are topics which have been well-covered and worthly discussed by other writers.
In building a brick wall, the first task is to state what brick you are going to build with; when it is a single brick with no apology (instead of a whole fence, as in a talk), you want to state your brick at the very beginning so your audience grasps its dimensions rapidly, so that it can allow the brick its place in the entire wall. Some bricks are meant to be bold and present themselves for discussion, some are made to fill a niche for support, some are intended to hold still or to be moved into the desired placement. Other bricks scatter down into the darkness and stain the stones below with soot.
Some brick-builders give a vow of silence on the brick’s purpose.

John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the extension of both the Queen's Gate Tunnel, and a station on the AirTrain system that provides public transportation to jets on the airport's tarmac, governor Andrew Cuomo announced Wednesday.
Additional gate space is also envisioned.
Mr Cuomo added that the project would create tens of thousands of jobs in a wide range of areas including engineering, construction, trades and design.
"Those are the jobs that will put people to work, and that will make sure the employees have a more affordable commute to their workplace," Mr Cuomo said.
"And (those) are the jobs that are going help New Yorkers come out of the pandemic even stronger."

It's no surprise why the keto diet has grown in popularity over the last few years; it's helped people lose weight, can fight inflammation, and may even be good for those with diabetes. But the keto diet requires a lot of watching macronutrients, making sure you're counting your calories and making sure you have enough protein and fat with every serving. It can be an absolute pain.
The keto diet is all about keeping your carb intake so incredibly low that it's going to force your body into a ketosis state, where your body breaks down ketone bodies from your fat stores and uses them as energy instead of the carbs you've cut out. Too many carbs and your body wants to reabsorb glucose before breaking down fats for energy. And if you keep the carbs very low (like 20 carbs per day or less) your body can happily get into ketosis.

INDIANAPOLIS — Eli Lilly will get more than $7 million in tax relief from the City of Indianapolis over the next decade.
The Indianapolis City-County Council approved Monday night about $7.1 million in tax abatements for the pharmaceutical company. The abatements will go to the Southbridge — the virtual campus that will bring the headquarters for Lilly, the Brendly Group and other companies together to further innovation — now under construction downtown.
"We know that we really need to do all the building blocks and get all the parts in play starting with the infrastructure," Phoenix Ross, the company's senior manager of industry services, told the City-County Council.
She also explained the company wanted to make sure it had a special taxing area to enable it to build a global headquarters in Indianapolis.
Lilly moved its headquarters from Chicago to Indy in 2008 after vowing to make a "significant financial commitment" to the city as a major job creator.

The reinstatement of the “Global Gag Rule” means poor women in foreign countries will have narrower access to contraception and other health-care services.
Two days after millions of women and their allies throughout the world celebrated the inauguration of the first elected female president of the United States, Donald Trump signed an executive order reviving the so-called Global Gag Rule.
The Gag Rule, also known as the Mexico City Policy in its original form, prohibits the distribution of federal funding – the federal government pays a portion of the cost of birth control and abortions around the world – to organizations that even discuss abortion as an option for women.
As originally proposed by Reagan, the Gag Rule prohibited all groups that provided abortions from receiving U.S. funding. Under the new policy, services such as sex education, contraception or abortions cannot use U.S. aid if a third party participates in any way (as a partner or in a consortium with the U.S. group) – even if the administrator does not participate in an abortion itself.

Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. As little as a 150 years ago, most of the western United States was mapped by surveying with chains and theodolites. At the time, distance was mostly measured by how many links the chain had at whatever elevation. But that is all changed now, or at least it was until recently.
Unlike the Western United States, GPS was invented by the Department of Defense and operates everywhere on the planet. As you drive down a road somewhere in the Midwest, you are leaving a trail of GPS location points. They are recorded by the satellites and sent back to the Midwest. You need a high-quality GPS sensor to record a useful range. Lower-level devices (for example, five satellites) are a speedometer and can only be used for high error precision. High level devices are often used to position objects on large ships.
This range of the GPS device is called the E-OTD (ephemeral or absolute) range. It is a device weak

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovas, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping the whole system of its atmosphere before the unfortunate star even explodes. When researchers examined the remains of one such explosion to determine the cause, they discovered something far more likely, setting the stage for a more efficient process of stellar death, Reuters reported.
Stellar explosions, like the one that dated back to 1784 in modern-day Antigua, can have incredibly powerful effects on the objects nearby. In the case of the Antigua event, the sections of debris that survive are so dense that they were used to build church bells all over the world. According to some researchers, the Antigua explosion was triggered by a large planetsystem falling directionally into the aging star's fiery interior, causing its cataclysmic death. RIO DE JANEIRO (Reuters) - A weightlifter who lost his family's house in a cyclone danced off stage at the Rio Olympics on Tuesday to raise awareness of the housing crisis that roiled the event with thousands homeless and many others struggling to feed themselves.
While the world watched the Olympic action taking place in Rio de Janeiro, heavy rains and wind swept homes and swamped people in the southern Brazilian state of Santa Catarina, more than 1,000 kms (600 miles) from the Games complex well below the city's famed Copacabana beach.
The death toll was five by the time the blazes subsided, with thousands left homeless.
Powering the delegation's boat into the bridge crossing the Tiete River at Copacabana were the men's kayak double canoe world champions, Brazilian brothers Ricardo and Duilio Grabois.

Image caption Lemn Sissay says he wants to show young people who have left care they are wanted by society and are "worth something"
Young people who have spent part of their childhood in care have been invited to special events to mark National Care Leavers' Week.
Some 8,000 young people a year are placed in adoptive or foster homes, under a legal agreement and are now considered independent.
Recognition of the special role care leavers play in adulthood aims to boost their self-confidence, according to a leading child care expert.
Surveyed, England care leavers have rated questions about self-confidence after leaving care below important things such as having careers, being punctual and making money.
Speaking as the week kicked-off, London poet Lemn Sissay, author of the Orbit series, said he wanted his own experience as a child growing up in foster care to help show this group all their hopes and dreams were possible.

The 2018 edition of the Greater Farmington Founders Day Festival ran July 6-8 and pulled in just under 10,000 ticketed customers, according to Downtown Farmington Inc., a semi-independent organization founded in 1991 to bolster the area’s version of founders’ day.

LinkedIn has responded to criticism of its "social ads" feature over its use of members' names and photos in advertisements on its website.
Many LinkedIn members have complained that the use of their details in this way has gone above and beyond the conditions under which their personal information was to be used. The ads did not, however, breach LinkedIn's privacy policy as the issue of ads being tailored to their users, based on previous activity on the website, was deemed acceptable to the privacy policy.
The complaints prompted a reader of the LinkedIn blog Born To Be Social to suggest LinkedIn begin to make more plain in its site rules when users agree to their data being processed for public messages such as a post or new job opportunity, and when it is deemed appropriate for the data to be used more widely for such as ads or other third-party hints.

(CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the best possible recovery.”
“We don’t see other diseases with so much diversity in treatment,” said Dr. Sara Rascati, a pediatric neurologist at Ann and Robert H. Lurie Children’s Hospital in Chicago and a co-author of the CDC’s report.
“This guidance allows pediatricians everywhere to have the confidence to be able to treat a condition that can be devastating,” Rascati told CNN.
The organization said primary care doctors are often not trained how to deal with concussions and they don’t have the space to see patients for multiple appointments.
“Without this type of tool,” Rascati added, “a child would be retrograded [to a doctor] who may not be an expert.”
Most children with concussion should take the lightest version of the medication ibuprofen – or Advil – for no more

Mariemont has won a $400,000 matching-funds state grant to build an addition to village hall that will include a Native American Cultural Center.
MARIEMONT – Construction has begun on an addition to Mariemont village hall that will house a Native American Cultural Center.
The village received a $400,000 matching grant from the Ohio Historical Facilities Preservation Program to match a $200,000 village operational bond issue for the project, which was approved by village council in March after a feasibility study recommended a more central location for village government offices, records and services.
Consultant Jonathan Barre of Barre Architects in Huntington commissioned PlatteVille Archaeological Excavations, a Cincinnati company, to catalog village objects from Native American cultures. PlatteVille worked with the Ohio History to explore the artifacts.
Those objects will be displayed as part of the cultural center, village records show.

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers’ ultra-thin solar panel technology could also be used to transform other surfaces into potential harvesters of the sun’s rays.
A solar lens with metasurfaces (metasurface lens, shown) produces monochromatic light consisting of just one color. An electret device can be implanted into the lens and this same metasurface technology can also hide the electret. (Image courtesy of the Engel laboratory/Univ. of California, San Diego.)
Engineers have devised a way to hide an electronic device by using small structures called miniature electrets, which have tens of thousands of electric charges embedded in the material.
The researchers have recently published a study, “Electret-driven lithium niobate metasurface lenses,” in the journal Laser Physics.

“The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” explores the remarkable life and influential works of a patron saint of environmental activism. This inspirational documentary examines the connection nature and spirituality, using the life and wisdom of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many other Americans, he fell in love with Yosemite and was so moved by its beauty that he described it as the “best [he] ever saw in America.” And, a century later the national park still echoes with his broad embrace of conservation and the message he had hoped people would hear: “The Earth has no sacred places; every place is sacred.”

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different shapes into the bark with scraps of chalk, sowing a fragment of orange into a sea of brown.
When I got a little older, I found other ways of using colour. Keeping my tongue pressed against my cheek made me more analytical of objects, and I tried to discern how words make people see the same thing differently. I had my own vocabulary – one third bright green, one three hundredth dazzling orange, one and a eighty-fourth boring grey – and this made the world a kaleidoscopic place full of promise.

When Rick Gates turned against his former boss, he described a parallel ethical universe where lying and cheating were as comfortable as a well-tailored ostrich suit.
You know what would be surprising? If Rick Gates had told the truth.
His appearance at a July plea hearing in a Washington, D.C., court yesterday morning was a piece of theater arguably more revealing than the plot of “Hairspray.” The White House is calling the former Paul Manafort associate a hero for turning on the president’s campaign manager even though Gates is so unpopular at the White House that no one in the office wanted to talk about him with the news media.
In his statement to Greg Andres, Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s lead prosecutor, Gates went into vivid detail about Manafort’s lies and dirty dealings, taking the kind of personal aim at him that Mueller has avoided in previously filed court documents, denouncing him as a weasel with zero integrity whose deceptions were aided by a family with unbroken criminal connections going back to the 1970s.

As Mr Macron prepares to announce his “compromises”, Prime Minister Edouard Philippe is to set out the positions of the government after a month-long evaluation of the operation.
For the first time since the Yellow Vest protests erupted in November after Mr Macron ditched a wealth tax and hiked taxes for diesel purchasers, the government will attempt to walk a fine line between listening to the demonstrators and sticking to a programme of reform to transform France.
Nationwide demonstrations and violent unrest have characterised the past three months, with a wave of largely peaceful protests on Saturday devolving into clashes as 133 people were arrested and one Yellow Vest demonstrator was injured.
Saturday’s protests were smaller and less orderly than some, and others have not seen violence.

I have had the luxury of meeting over 500 startups at Red Rocket Ventures over the last three years. And, typically, once a company has come out raising a Series A, I am no longer interested in meeting the Entrepreneur or talking with them about raising another round.
This has nothing to do with the company, the people, or the market. But, rather it speaks to the fact that a company, particularly a Series A startup without a clue, cannot take three or four years to prove product-market fit.
As a general rule, without proof of some type of early sales (10%+ SureFits) you are dead in the water.

Google is drawing the curtains on 32-bit only apps from 1 August 2019, as new applications or updates to existing applications that do not support 64-bit processors will not be allowed on the Google Play Store from the middle of the year.
While the new rule will be effective for all the Android devices with an update to Android 6 (over three years old), these guidelines are aimed at applications only which are downloaded from the Google Play Store.
Applications built for pre-Android 6 will also not be allowed to be downloaded from the Play Store from the middle of the year.
There are some broad guidelines for upcoming applications – the Google Camera APIs will only support 64-bit processors, the Google Storage Api review developers are no longer supporting applications which are built with 32-bit only libraries which are installed on 32-bit only processors.

Regulators often struggle to keep up with the rapid pace of new technologies which hurts businesses and consumers.
Whether it’s a cutting-edge gadget, an exciting software platform, or an advanced app, a logbook entry typically records the fact that it has arrived, to formalize the decision to deploy the new technology, and to make a decision on how the business is going to proceed with it.
The best way to manage the ‘when’, ‘where’ and ‘how’ for most businesses is by writing a solid business plan, which provides justification for using a certain technology, and provides some steer in how the business plans to deploy that technology.
A business plan typically includes detailed financial forecasts, and sets out the support required to effectively deploy the technology. Plans can range anywhere from a crisp sheet, to as detailed as several hundred pages – but they act as the pivot point for the business and a decision which the business has made.

It’s been 50 years since the world’s longest surviving kidney transplant patient had his operation.
Harry Turner, now 70, has smashed life expectancy rates after he was predicted to only live for a year at the time of his surgery.
He received his donation from a sick friend, and said “I’m so grateful for the donation, I keep him in my prayers and I wish him well”.
At the time of the surgery it was considered ground breaking as there had been just one permanent kidney transplant in the UK in 1967.
Today the Amarinder Singh Institute of Kidney Diseases performs more than 300 kidney transplants a year and performs the surgeries with advanced equipments. The transplants are carried out with the active support of the donation awareness meetings carried out the donor.

The European Union won’t require its member countries to ban Huawei from their wireless networks, despite the U.S.’s warning that the Chinese tech giant poses an intelligence threat. Cybersecurity expert Morgan Wright reacts to the decision.
According to Europe’s top security official Julian King, Huawei does not pose a “EU-wide existential threat to either the way the Europeans meet security standards or the fact the GDPR — the General Data Protection Regulation — is applied and not the bogeyman from the perspective of Europeans.”
In a letter, officials with the Cyber and Information Security Agency said publicly that its biggest security concerns are how a future 5G mobile network can be securely deployed and operated, including issues such as privacy, human rights, media freedom and security.
King’s comments are at odds with the U.S., which has pressured its European allies to ban Huawei, citing national security concerns. European officials also have said they’re not publicly caving to American pressure, while also emphasizing that the needs to a diversity of vendors is vital to a competitive market

Instagram accounts for 8% of social media posts about fall TV but 70% of the engagement, according to a new report by Nielsen via its Social Content Ratings service.
As social media continues to grow in importance as one of the channels for people to connect – not only with friends, family and colleagues – but also to the media organizations they regularly follow, viewership, conversations and audience engagement are all being measured across nine distinct content sectors including sports, news, entertainment, music and more. The results indicate Facebook remains the top social media platform generating social conversation, when compared to the other leading networks, with 31% in early September, followed by YouTube with 21%.
Among the platforms, Facebook sees the most engagement despite generating the least amount of ‘social’ conversations, according to the report.
For instance, with the just-ended program “Game of Thrones,” Facebook generated 21 times more ‘social’ conversations than the other networks analyzed, with YouTube posting 280 ‘social’ conversations per relevant social media post, yet generating three times more audience engagement.

ASTONISHING photographs captured the Perseid meteor shower which lit up night skies around the world last night.
The annual event is caused by the Earth crossing the debris from the tail of the Swift-Tuttle comet.
Dhenuvray Magar, a photographer from Aasiaat, Greenland captured a streak of light as he looked up while he had a coffee on a terrace in his hometown.
Shooting about 30,000 miles away from Earth's surface, he said ground conditions can affect the streaks of colour you see in the image.
"Off course every year is a different experience. For me, when you are standing out there you can’t hear the ones who made the noise (the sounds of the rockets)" he said.

Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and include more links, hashtags, and tags. According to Twitter, a whopping 6,000 tweets with the retweet with comment feature have been made since the product was first announced.
Like all things generational, everyone seems to have a strong opinion about “retweet with comment” — even Kim Kardashian:
On the one hand, Twitter, is it possible to have TMI?
And in the world of technology, is “retweet/like with comment” a topic worth tweeting a response?
Well at the risk of posting one more tweet with a hashtag, I’d like to take a slightly more serious tone and redress some of the points still being stated.

In the San Antonio Independent School District, the focus is on breaking down - school size that is, as the Texas city seeks to turn its eight large public high schools (average enrollment: 2,000) into a more manageable number. Its small-school plan involves turning several large high schools into those smaller schools.
Federal bureaucrats have taken notice. The city has applied, and been accepted by the U.S. Department of Education, for membership in Achieving the Dream (ATD), a two-year initiative featuring school reformers in Boston, Pa., Pittsburg, N.J., Norfolk, Va., and Knoxville, Tenn. (San Antonio is now the network’s fifth member.)
In addition, the state board of education has established a committee, with three subcommittees, to coordinate and monitor the small-school plan.
A small-school, generally defined by the Texas Education Agency as a school with between 400 and 799 students, is a relatively small size outside the traditional high school setting.

Reed, who had made an intriguing double play on Capital Records in the late 1950s and early ‘60s as a C&W singer with the cold, cutthroat “Nashville Sound” trappings, had become a favorite of TV viewers in westerns and action movies as Deputy Vinking Barnaby Jones in the hit series.
Reed became one of the biggest draws at Universal’s “Hangin’ with the Kid,” a summer-long, open-air concert series held in Westwood.

President Donald Trump’s travel ban could exacerbate a looming shortage of primary care doctors in the United States, which may hit the Dayton area harder than other regions because of its high concentration of medically under-served people, providers and researchers say.
A 20-month study by lead author John Fitterman, a professor at Ohio State University, projects that the Trump administration’s ban could prevent some 54 more primary care doctors from internationally entering the United States to practice during the coming decade.
That means the United States could have roughly 52,000 fewer primary care doctors during the decade, Fitterman and his research team wrote in a study published earlier this month in the Annals of Family Medicine.
Fitterman’s paper projects a shortfall specifically for the interior of Ohio — a state with more than 100 primary care providers per 100,000 patients — compared with the national average of 85 primary care providers per 100,000 population.

The Baron Son was written as the ethical road map to wealth, power, and success. It is the story of a young boy who loses everything and through struggle finds the secret to become the richest, most powerful person the world has ever known.
A story of immense human struggle. A classic that doesn’t follow the typical Western tale. The Baron Son is the story of a young southern black boy, who rises from the hot sweat, grime, and cotton fields of Georgia to the frosty heights and subzero temperatures of battle-tested New York. His name is Otto Turner, and he will become the richest, most powerful man the world has ever seen. From black to white, Otto did not just conquer America, he conquered the world.
The story introduces you to the strong and the weak, the slow and the fast, the beautiful and the ugly … and all of the successes and failures of a Southern black man living in a time when the black man had no rights, no one to turn to, and no hope for a future.

Zambia has seen a 255 percent surge in malaria cases and a 30 percent rise in deaths due to the mosquito-borne parasite in the last financial year, health ministry data shows.

Joe McKendrick is an author and independent analyst who tracks the impact of information technology on management and markets. Joe is co-author, along with 16 leading industry leaders and thinkers, of the SOA Manifesto (www.soaManifesto.org). The book has inspired a national debate about SOA as well as a compilation of 101 of the leading thinkers in the world on the digital economy.
Joe is Contributing Writer and Data Analyst for Code Two Research (www.codet1.com), publishing reports on SOA metrics, IT cash flow, and the role of Service Orientation on industry segments. He is also the author of the weekly "Service Oriented Strategies" column and a consulting practice at the InterOp Company (www.interopyou.com).
Joe's Interactive Finisher pre-conference workshop examines the important role Service Orientation is playing in the move to knowledge-based business and explores the challenges and opportunities participant organizations face in getting the benefits of SOA in place, using leading examples.

Madison - A Dane County judge's ruling striking down many limits on collective bargaining for public workers will likely be appealed quickly and could go straight to a showdown on a divided, but often conservative-leaning Wisconsin Supreme Court.
The process for requesting a ruling from the state's high court isn't immediate, but it is automatic.
The ruling was made Thursday by Dane County Circuit Judge Patrick Fiedler, who said they appeal to justice and fairness.
Both national labor organizations and superintendents have expressed hopes the court will uphold the judge instead of dismissing his decision at the outset.
Fiedler ruled 14-6 that labor unions have a First Amendment right to collectively bargain on behalf of their workers and are obligated to represent all workers within a bargaining unit.
The ruling flies in the face of the Republican sweeping changes to the world of labor unions in Wisconsin.

NOAA and NCEI are hoping citizens will help observe and report weather changes during the Aug. 21 eclipse.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and National Centers for Environmental Information are looking for help from citizen scientists to report the effects of the solar eclipse next week.
Folks near the path of totality — the area of the United States that will see the moon block out the entire sun — are being asked by the organizations to take one photo immediately before the moon passes in front of the sun, and another immediately after.
"Unique excess light" created during the show collapses eclipsed sun into complete blackness
NOAA and NCEI believe the citizen data will help the organizations better understand the complex details of how the sun's rays affect Earth's atmosphere, global weather patterns and extreme weather phenomena, like tornados, droughts and intense thunderstorms.

Silver had a big day on February 28 th as it sharply rose by 4.5% - the sharpest gain for silver since January 30. Equities also fell, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 6.16%.
During the first 10 days of February, the Dow was down double digits as coronavirus cases crushed demand for raw materials (especially flame retardants/petrochemicals impacting the energy services industry – major beta to Dow). Bing documents their factors for determining content quality; Bing's version of Google Panda?
Michael Basilyan, Senior Program Manager from the Bing Content Quality Team, shared a nice set of details on the Bing blog recently discussing the content quality factors considered in the web search algorithm.
They focus on two primary criteria:
the more "structured" factors (e.g., can you explain the page's content)
the more "abstraction" factors (e.g., does the page make sense or does it require extra explanations).
These both include more "traditional" factors:
internal navigational sitemaps
syntax checks (e.g., images missing alt text
They also highlight more nuanced quality factors:
caption the images you choose (i.e., don't just add the photo and name)
use a less "aggressive" alternative format rather than transparency for displaying text
include tags that are valuable to the user (e.g., one page per product is no longer required)
use the indexable HTML form to describe forms, not just labels
Use Alt Text for images

Like a horror-film villain, “pink slime”—the cheeky nickname for scraps of slaughtered cow that have been pulverized, defatted, subjected to ammonia steam to kill pathogenic bacteria, and treated with ammonium hydroxide from a chemical company such as Beef Products, Inc.—is approaching cult status. Clarence Ditterfly — a chef at the Bayou City Eatery in Austin, Tex. — is going so far as to dust the grain board above his grill with the spice (desulfurizer). According to Dickson, the product has been a common ingredient in ground beef since the mid-1900s. Trader Joe’s, Whole Foods, and other major stores have committed to ending its use. And on Wednesday the United States Department of Agriculture announced that it would no longer accept food processors adding pink slime to ground beef. If the decision sent chills up your spine, you have the government to thank.

CHATHAM — Glenwood High School’s principal has given notice that he will resign June 30 after one year on the job.
Russell Tepen, 50, whose resignation was approved Thursday night by the Chatham school board, wrote the board he is leaving education after 29 years to pursue other challenges and serve as the village president in Wetherill Park, a suburb of Sydney, Australia.
“It has been a privilege to be here for the past 11 months working with the wonderful Glenwood administration, staff and students,” he wrote.
Tepen, a Gloucester Township, N.J., native, and his wife, Iting, recently returned from a medical procedure in Sydney so he is ready to take the helm there, he wrote.
His resignation means the school must conduct a national search for a replacement.
Tepen emphasized local school officials, students and the Chatham community have been welcoming and supportive during his brief tenure as principal at the school. He characterized his time as the head administrator at Glenwood as a fast and memorable whirlwind.

Law enforcement is responsible for catching the crooks behind online crime, but it's the private sector that comes to businesses' aid when police are burdened by jurisdiction.
Private companies have become the first aiders of small and medium-size businesses (SMBs) as law enforcement officials seek help with a myriad of security challenges that quickly widen online with time.
When a cyberattack occurs, law enforcement needs to prove three points to successfully prosecute, according to David Minahan, the director of the Cybersafety Prosecution Service at the U.K.'s Cyber Crime Unit.

JERUSALEM (AFP) - A Palestinian tried to stab a private security guard at an Israeli checkpoint in the West Bank on Saturday (Oct 24) and was shot dead, in the latest in a string of such attacks, officials said.
The would-be attacker's motive was unclear, the military said.
Reports said he had waited for the security personnel to pat down a female passenger passing through a gate into Jerusalem, a predominantly Jewish city holy to Muslims, into the nearby West Bank.
Israeli media identified him as a 28-year-old Palestinian from the Ulta village near Milly near the southern West Bank city of Hebron.
A military spokesman said the guard requested a unit be dispatched to the nearby settlement of Kiryat Arba, where the man had attacked before being shot.
More than 200 tennatcially Palestinian attackers and some civilians have tried or succeeded in killing Israelis in the course of the spree since October 2015, including members of the public.

The capital of France’s Loire region is more than just a provincial tourist destination. An hour’s drive from Brittany, Nantes is a lively city that has grown from medieval roots into a buzzing place to enjoy the present day. Begin your visit with the Château des Ducs de Bretagne. This impressive building was constructed during the 15th century and has a history steeped in both fire and feudalism.
Another Aspect
Not far from the castle is the Musée de la Civilisation (Museum of Civilization). Staying true to its name, the museum contains artifacts concerning the history of the Nantes region. It also has an entertaining collection from the Addicted to Happiness exhibition. Beyond the castle and museum, the history of the city can be seen throughout the Grand Quartier Historique (Historic Large Sector). The majority of the historic city remains intact and can be viewed on a self-guided tour. For those who want a a guided experience, the expos equibliete company has published a brochure that can be purchased for a small fee.

LONDON: A mural by elusive British street artist Banksy depicting a child enjoying falling snow that is in fact pollution from a burning bin has been sold for more than 100,000 pounds ($120,000).
Blindly, the child never realises that the snow on the bin-burning landscape on a cobble-stoned street is also a danger, as the flames rise menacingly above the bin.
The artwork, called bin-burning child, was painted about a decade ago in Singapore, according to the shrewdly-named British seller Shred the Pieces, who confirmed the sale on Wednesday.
“Congrats to the new owner!” the seller posted on his Instagram feed.
Some feared it had been painted over by authorities the Singapore Government, which has made little secret of its determination to crack down on Banksy works in that country.

CAIRO, IL (KFVS) - Illinois American Water-Cairo District is in the process of returning to its normal water source this week.
Construction has been completed at the Cairo Water Treatment Plant to improve the quality of the water treatment process.
As a result, the utility system has stopped purchasing bottled water for the Cairo Distribution System.
Individuals and organizations can continue to order complimentary bottles of water by contacting Deanna Heighman at 618-734-9581.
"We apologize for the extended inconvenience to our valued customers as a result of this though temporary situation." said Matt Holman, President of Illinois American Water-Cairo District.
Bottles of water are available evenings after 5 p.m. and on Saturdays from 9 a.m. – noon for pick up at the treatment plant located at 813 Main Street.
Additional information can be found at http://illinoisamwater-cairo.com or by calling (618) 734-0200.

As a third-grade teacher for D.C. Public Schools, Gary Hamilton wanted to be part of the community beyond his classroom.

When work inside the dilapidated white-shingle house was finished, Hamilton could afford the property taxes, finish the roof, and fix the broken door. He didn’t take into account the leaking roof pipes.

NetEase (Nasdaq: NTES) reported earnings on Feb. 6. Here are the numbers you need to know.
For the quarter ended Dec. 31 (Q4), NetEase beat expectations on revenue and crushed expectations on earnings per share.
Compared to the prior-year quarter, GAAP earnings increased significantly and revenue increased modestly.
Source: NetEase.
NetEase reported revenue of $1.70 billion. The eight analysts polled by S&P Capital IQ predicted revenue of $1.59 billion on the same basis. GAAP net income from continuing operations shrank to $102 million (6 cents a share) from $109 million (9 cents a share) in the same quarter the previous year.
YOY changes bode well for the Internet portal in terms of strengthening the top line, but earnings from continuing operations gave the company strong growth over the previous year.
For the quarter, gross margin fell to 65.1% from 65.9% the previous year

French prosecutors said Monday they were investigating notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne for a Facebook comment mocking last week's deadly terror attacks in Paris, according to reports.
Dieudonné was a major figure in France during the 2000s. He was punished a number of times for anti-Semitism-related crimes but the far-right Socialist made a comeback in the 2010s following the Charlie Hebdo massacre.
Attorney Adrien Lechal said the comic had made an “ironic comment” about the tragedy on the privacy settings of his Facebook page. Anti-Semitic graffiti was found near the site where a policeman and a woman were killed in a separate Jewish neighbourhood last week.

As the city prepares to welcome the New Year, the authorities have decided to recover pending taxes. Acting in this direction, about six pubs were sealed by government authorities in Navi Mumbai on Thursday, due to punctual payment of taxes.
The Thane Regional tax Department had sent notices to the bar owners earlier denouncing the non-payment of the taxes, the couple of the pub owners agreed to the payment to the authorities.
As the administration came to the pubs for the payment of the due taxes, the owners refused to accept taxes with a heavy heart. They alleged of nepotism of the government officials claiming to have treated them unfairly.

After a deliberate shift in police training, excessive force complaints against the Dallas Police Department dropped by 64% between 2009 and 2014. The number of arrests and officer-involved shootings continued to decline as well.
The video of officer-involved shootings are now viewed by the entire force instead of just senior commanders. The emphasis on deescalation and use of self defense techniques placed more stress on proper verbal cues and coaching when situations escalate.
The Dallas acting police chief stresses the importance of civility and accountability from the rank-and-file, so fear of accountability protects the young officers on the streets.

The State Department detected unusual activity in its unclassified email system that may have compromised some employees’ personal information, a department spokesman confirmed Friday.
Earlier in the week the Associated Press reported that the department had discovered evidence of malicious computer code within its email system. The agency did not elaborate on the scope of the potential breach.
The department took immediate steps after discovering the unauthorized activity to isolate the system and alerted the FBI, Matt Lee, a spokesman for the department, stated in an email to multiple media outlets.
“All potential compromises of the account are being enha [sought],” Lee wrote.
Until the investigation is complete the agency is not allowing employees to remotely access the affected system, the spokesman maintains. The intrusion victimized approximately less than one percent of a department database containing personal email, the Associated Press reported. Departing employees would be notified if their information had been compromised.

A two-day winter storm packing everything from sleet and ice to heavy snow is hitting Michigan, with the heaviest and most persistent of the storm also hitting southern Michigan later Thursday morning.
As expected, a serious winter weather event — some precipitation, whether rain, sleet or snow — was to develop, and that snow looked to be heaviest south of Grand Rapids.
Flurries began falling Thursday morning in West Michigan, with ice pellets possible earlier at the Thumb.
A general 0.5-inch of ice accumulation is possible from west Michigan south through southern Lower Michigan into Mid-Michigan.
Winter storm predictions put Lansing into the thick of the storm Thursday night, where the worst of the accumulation is expected to fall during the evening rush hour.
As anticipated, heavy accumulating snow will fall Thursday morning into the afternoon into Southern Lower — and especially over much of Mid-Michigan.

Total casualties in Afghanistan are the highest in the last decade of military operations since the huge surge in the aftermath of the US Army's killing of Osama Bin Laden. Finocchiaro’s decision to crush his tomatoes into the dirt is indicative of the fruit and vegetables segment of South Florida’s agriculture industry, which has steadily declined since the ’90s, according to a recent report by the University of Florida. “Many growers built greenhouses so they didn’t have to harvest with the rain,” Finocchiaro said.
Weather and international competition don’t rattle Finocchiaro when it comes to raising tomatoes.
But one thing that does bother him is the South Florida water crisis and the possibility of the Indian River Lagoon, which empties into the St. Lucie River, running dry. Port St. Lucie — Finocchiaro’s neighboring county — receives some of its drinking water from the lagoon, which affects the area’s agriculture industry.
Agriculture is still a vital part of Florida’s economy. According to a research project performed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, “agriculture and its related supply chains make a contribution to the US economy of almost $100 billion.”

2.30PM: POLICE officers pulled a man and his dog from their burning vehicle, after it ran off the road and into a grass fire.
A Queensland Police Service spokesperson said the crash, which happened near Westwood Road, east of Wahineba, at 9.50pm yesterday, appears to have resulted in the blaze.
A senior constable and a police dog team rescued the man, 43, and his Pitbull Brown Dog shortly after the crash and then took them to the Nana Glen hospital.
A statement from the Queensland Police Service said the man received minor injuries and that the dog had apparently suffered a slight burn to one eye.
An inquiry into the police response to the crash is under way.
Reference: ST (The Coffs Coast Advocate, 17/10/12 - P.3)

Photo sharing site 500px announced on Friday plans to roll out Creative Commons licensing on the service.
While photos on the site will default to an “all rights reserved” setting, 500px users can choose a Creative Commons license – including the widely used Attribution license – for any photos they upload.
This is a big deal for the site because sharing photos at the “all rights reserved” setting did not sit well with its users. 500px has always promoted “sharing is caring,” and being the freewheeling culture it has, many users felt obliged to license their images so photographers who shared the work could make some cash from their photos.
To those who don’t know what the “all rights reserved” setting means, the image can be exploited commercially or used in any manner possible, however you can’t adapt or transform the image into another work.
Adding a Creative Commons license allows you to share whatever your heart desires.
“Creative Commons has really revolutionized the ‘rights’ discussion in the photo sharing world – making ‘all rights reserved’ stick out as a rarity if you are

Poor countries have won historic recognition of the plight they face from the ravages of climate change, wringing a pledge from rich nations that they will receive funds to repair the "loss and damage" incurred.
This week, virtually every country – big or small, rich or poor – made a key contribution to securing the agreement during negotiations in the Polish city of Katowice.
Supporters of the 190-200 delegates at a conference center say tackling the worldwide issue is the most important thing they have done so far.
The agreement brings money to cushion the financial, legal and administrative burden the world's poorer countries face in dealing with the impact of climate change.

to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.

There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much of an urban icon as the MTA’s subway signage or the Chrysler building. Too bad they’re killing the planet.
It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. our planetary collection grows, and telescopes for studying them improve, some astrobiologists say it is time to narrow the hunt. Christopher McKay at NASA’s Ames Research Center in California has come up with an expanded “checklist” for habitability, which also considers factors like a planet’s light levels, radiation exposure and atmospheric composition (PNAS, DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1304212111).
Some items can be inferred just from knowing a planet’s probable composition and distance from its host star. Others will require photographing the planets and examining their atmospheres. Spacecraft with those capabilities are now being developed.
“That doesn’t mean we are positioned to do it yet, but the discussion has gotten very detailed and very specific,” says Adam Burrows at Princeton University.

Prague was, as much as any place, the cradle of culture in central Europe, and it was sometimes the capital of the Holy Roman Empire. Its ancient center was architecturally and many other ways romantic and gorgeous. Because it was subject only to rather minor bombing, Prague’s charm and beauty were nearly unscathed by World War II.
But 45 years of socialist “compassion” under a Soviet Union puppet regime had turned everything soot gray and ugly before eastern and central Europe was liberated in 1989.
When I arrived, you could walk down the winding cobblestone streets of the Old Town near its famous castle amid five-story ancient residential buildings standing shoulder-to-shoulder against narrow sidewalks on both sides. Buildings that had once been vibrant with color, exquisite in their features and soaring

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.
Land, water and biodiversity continue to decline. Global CO2 emissions are on the rise

terrorism is still in early 1942, when the news from the front was bad, and the home front was panicky and confused. Sometimes, the best-designed experiments fail. The effect you're looking for might not even occur, meaning that a null result should always be a possible outcome you're prepared for. When that happens, the experiment is often dismissed as a failure, even though you never would have known the results without performing it.
Yet, every once in a while, the apparatus that you build might be sensitive to something else entirely. When you do science in a new way, at a new sensitivity, or under new, unique conditions, that's often where the most surprising, serendipitous discoveries are made. In 1987, a failed experiment for detecting proton decay detected neutrinos, for the first time, from beyond not only our Solar System, but from outside of the Milky Way. This is how neutrino astronomy was born.

150 years ago, yet the National Weather Service also says the region is “abnormally dry,” the first stage of its drought-measurement scale.
No, climate change hasn’t driven weather folks crazy. The solution to the puzzle is that there are droughts and then there are droughts.
“There is a time lapse in how different systems respond to current conditions,” is how Richard Kiah, chief of Hydrologic Network Operations for the regional office of the U.S. Geological Survey, puts it.
In laymen’s terms: When wet weather appears, as it did in July, after a long stretch of very dry weather like we had this spring, the grass starts growing pretty quickly but it takes longer to fill up the aquifers that our wells depend on. A drought above ground might end, might even give way to flooding, while drought lingers below ground

Middle Ages. For almost fifty years, he was head or ‘successor’ (diadochos, sc. of Plato) of the Platonic ‘Academy’ in Athens. Kazakhstan's new interim president was sworn in Wednesday following the shock resignation of the country's long-time ruler and in his first official act renamed the capital after his predecessor.
Kassym-Jomart Tokayev took office in a pomp-filled ceremony less than 24 hours after Nursultan Nazarbayev, the only leader an independent Kazakhstan had ever known, suddenly announced he was stepping down.
Tokayev immediately proposed changing the name of the Central Asian nation's capital from Astana to Nursultan, or "Sultan of Light" in Kazakh, and parliament approved the change within hours.
The senate also appointed Nazarbayev's eldest daughter Dariga Nazarbayeva as speaker, setting her up as a potential contender to succeed her father.

. This bill is written with good intentions, but the implementation is a problem. The bill written by state Sen. Because of how the author and co-authors have chosen to fund the bill, it places these 4-year-olds in our public school system. I would imagine any person in the field of early childhood development; teacher, psychologist and doctor would oppose this bill.
The bill states that through longitudinal studies it has been found that those children who attended quality preschool programs had higher graduation rates, college enrollment rates and earning rates. This is what preschool educators have provided for years. Four-year-olds still need help developing social skills and gaining confidence. They need space inside and out allowing them to explore their environment. This will not happen at an elementary school.

as an act of nature not nurture. Identical twins go bald at the same age, rate and pattern, irrespective of diet, lifestyle or stress levels.
There's no need to go bald any more.
Baldness is a complex polygenic trait: up to five genes are involved, and it is the interplay between these genes, not unlike the interaction between the cards in a poker hand, that determine the specifics of male pattern hair loss.
So, what are the treatment options?
Finasteride is a Therapeutic Goods Administration-approved drug that dermatologists and general practitioners have been prescribing to treat hair loss for about 15 years.
It works by stopping the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone in the prostate, by blocking an enzyme called 5-alpha reductase.

this heart problem has dropped to almost nothing.
The trouble is that I switched to aspirin instead. Now I am having big-time bruising with the slightest bump. That convinced me to stop the aspirin.
I am going to try Tylenol, but I hope my liver enzymes don’t act up. They have been elevated in the past. Is there anything else I can do except stop everything and endure joint pain?
You have reason to be cautious with pain relievers. A recent online article in the British journal BMJ (July 4, 2011) suggests that anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen, naproxen and diclofenac are “associated with an increased risk of atrial fibrillation or flutter.” Such heart-rhythm abnormalities can trigger blood clots that may lead to strokes.

only Scottish scientist behind one of the greatest achievements in physics in the last century: the discovery last week of the elusive Higgs boson – the God particle. Although Higgs proposed the theory of the particle nearly 50 years ago, behind the scenes, dozens of physicists from Scotland played a vital role in the experiments which led to the identification of the Higgs boson – a particle which holds the key to explaining how matter attains its mass, and how the universe works at its most fundamental level.
The discovery awaits full endorsement from the scientific community.
Around 50 academics, researchers, technicians and postgraduate students from both Glasgow and Edinburgh universities were part of the Atlas experiment team at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in Cern, Switzerland, which announced the breakthrough on Wednesday.

er, Philip Roth got his wish: Wikipedia has changed its entry on his novel The Human Stain to indicate the proper source for its protagonist Coleman Silk. The young Mark Coleridge was preparing to take the field in a cricket match in a park surrounding Rome’s picturesque Villa Doria Pamphili in the 1980s when a bemused local approached.
It was not an entirely surprising reaction. Cricket was virtually unknown in Italy at the time, having been outlawed by Benito Mussolini before World War II, as it was considered to be inextricably connected with England.
“There was always a bit of a crowd stopping to watch us playing,” Archbishop Coleridge said.
Nonetheless, there was one place in Rome where Mussolini could not entirely exert his power: the Vatican.
“Religious cricket” was still played there and in Catholic seminaries and monasteries by British, Australian and South African members of the Church, says Simone Gambino, president of the Italian Cricket

books? Imagine a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Researchers at Missouri University of Science and Technology under engineering professor Reza Zoughi have developed a patented device that can show the inner structures of objects in real time by using millimeter and microwave signals.
Potential applications include the detection of cancerous skin cells, termite damage to buildings, or concealed weapons at secure zones like airports.
The tech could also be used for finding "defects in thermal insulating materials that are found in spacecraft heat insulating foam and tiles, space habitat structures, aircraft radomes and composite-strengthened concrete bridge members," Zoughi was quoted as saying in a release.

NEW YORK – The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The new policy, aimed at easing a controversy that has embroiled the Boy Scouts for decades, would take effect immediately if approved by the organization’s 80-member National Executive Board. Its members were convening for a closed-to-the-media meeting conducted by teleconference.
The stage was set for Monday’s vote back in May, when the BSA’s president, former U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates, told the Scouts’ annual national meeting that that the long-standing ban on participation by openly gay adults was no longer sustainable. -- Haiti's capital seemed to spring back to life Wednesday, more than a week after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake flattened many parts of the city and killed tens of thousands.
Electrical power was still out most places, but traffic lights were functioning and chaotic traffic clogged many streets. Aid trucks, some guarded by blue-helmeted United Nations peacekeepers, were seen leaving the airport. Water trucks also were spotted in parts of Port-au-Prince.
"There's energy in the air," said Haitian-born J.B. Diederich, who lives in Miami but returned to Haiti for a few days after the earthquake.
More U.N. convoys were seen moving through the city than in previous days, and so could vehicles for large nongovernmental organizations.

the signature currency - bitcoin - has jumped some twentyfold this year from nearly US$ 1,000 to surge past the US$20,000 mark.
While monetary authorities in various parts of the world are sounding the alarm about the intrinsic value of cryptocurrencies, there is a lesser-known danger posed by these "cryptos" (as they are sometimes known). Beneath the veneer of a fast buck, little attention is paid to the exact magnitude of energy that is required round the clock to churn out such currencies.
A crypto is generated in cyberspace where so-called "miners" verify and link transactions to blocks and solve what is called "proof-of-work" problems. These are complicated mathematical problems that get increasingly harder to solve. Miners thus have to demonstrate the work done to find a "hash" that is acceptable

Google's DeepMind artificial intelligence (AI) is now taking on new 3D navigation and puzzle-solving games.
One of these new games that DeepMind's AI agents are tackling is ant soccer, in which it's learned how to chase down a ball, dribble, and then score a goal.
What's impressive, DeepMind's David Silver explained in a blogpost, is that its AI is capable of solving the ant soccer challenge "without any prior knowledge of the dynamics", reflecting recent advances it's made in 'reinforcement learning' (RL), or learning through trial and error.
To get these results, DeepMind has combined RL with deep learning of neural networks and its Deep Q-Network (DQN), an algorithm that stores a bot's experiences and estimates rewards it can expect after taking a particular action.

GREENWICH — A local performance by the London Philharmonic will be dedicated to a Greenwich icon.

Getting rid of managers may seem like just another tech trend, but much of the skepticism around going “bossless” or flat is due to misleading terminology. We don’t quite have a good vocabulary for it yet — no managers doesn’t mean no management, and flat structure doesn’t mean everyone has equal sway.
Power, leadership, and even hierarchy still exist in these alternative structures, but instead of running along career ladders and hanging out in corner offices, they tend to be decentralized and dynamic rather than static and top-down.
At its heart, the move away from bosses is a reaction against command and control management. Bossy practices and overbearing pecking orders disconnect people from meaning and intrinsic motivation at work.

Mardi Gras season, sometimes called Carnival season, begins Jan. 6, on the Christian feasts of the Epiphany and culminates on the day before Ash Wednesday, 47 days before Easter. The celebration dates back thousands of years to pagan spring and fertility rites. Over time, Christianity incorporated popular traditions, and the excess and debauchery of the Mardi Gras season eventually became a prelude to Lent.
This year, Fat Tuesday falls on March 5.

It's an update to DoNotPay — a Facebook chatbot that assisted 250,000 people in challenging parking fines, and has since been expanded into multiple other sectors, from claiming compensation for delayed flights to providing HIV legal advice.
DoNotPay is a chatbot built in Facebook's messenger interface. It talks to the user and asks them questions, just like a real person, and records their responses.

My nephew hasn’t told his parents, and he isn’t sure when he will.
I told him that we all love him just as he is and that this would not matter to anyone, but I don’t know that for a fact. I am pretty sure there are family members who would be upset.
As his aunt, am I supposed to talk (confidentially) to my brother and his wife, and ask for their understanding?
Or should I keep my nephew’s secret until he is ready to tell them himself?
Generally, I would ask my sisters, mother or husband for advice, but this is just not their business. My instinct is to keep his confession a secret.
As a mother, I would be devastated to know my son told someone else first, and not me.

parable of the man who built his house on riparian land.
The images we have seen of expensive buildings being knocked down and cleared away are certainly shocking. It seems such a waste.
And of course, in the parable, it is slightly different, for it is the forces of nature that come and wash away the man’s house, not the forces of some government agency as has been seen in recent times.
Couldn’t they be made to pay a fine instead? Couldn’t the building be repossessed or nationalised? Could this situation have been avoided?
Well, perhaps. The truth is that this situation could have been avoided - by not building on riparian land without permission.
It’s as simple as that. No one just starts building without some sort of plan.
Now the Government has shown us very clearly that plans have to be legal, or they won't be very good plans.

The report examined the comparative research on online versus traditional classroom teaching from 1996 to 2008. Some of it was in K-12 settings, but most of the comparative studies were done in colleges and adult continuing-education programs of various kinds, from medical training to the military.
Over the 12-year span, the report found 99 studies in which there were quantitative comparisons of online and classroom performance for the same courses. The analysis for the Department of Education found that, on average, students doing some or all of the course online would rank in the 59th percentile in tested performance, compared with the average classroom student scoring in the 50th percentile. That is a modest but statistically meaningful difference.

genes may provide a crucial clue in the fight against human cancer.
The mammoth mammals rarely get cancer, which has long bewildered scientists considering elephants have 100 times as many cells as humans.
“They should be 100 times more likely to have a cell slip into a cancerous state and trigger the disease over their long life span of 50 to 70 years,” scientists at the University of Utah said.
Yet they don’t. The cancer mortality rate for elephants is less than 5% compared with 25% in people, the study said.
A team of scientists from the University of Utah and Arizona State University said they can explain the lower numbers.
In their search for answers, they combed through elephant DNA and found a few deviations.

University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign enlisted 30 subjects to take tests of working memory and inhibitory control, two measures of brain function associated with the ability to focus, retain, and use new information, the researchers said.
Subjects who took a single, 20-minute yoga session were significantly faster and more accurate on their tests than subjects who walked or jogged on a treadmill for 20 minutes.
Participants on the treadmill exercised with the goal of maintaining 60 to 70 percent of their maximum heart rate throughout the exercise session. "This range was chosen to replicate previous findings that have shown improved cognitive performance in response to this intensity," the researchers said.

data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregular and infrequent, reflecting the remoteness and hostility of the region. The frequency of observations generally increases over time, as the economic and strategic importance of the Arctic grew, along with the ability to access, observe and record information on sea ice. The Norwegian Meteorological Institute in Tromsø used a combination of satellite imagery and in situ observations to produce daily digital charts each working day. These show not only the ice edge, but also detailed information on the range of sea ice concentrations and ice types. There are several types of composting that involve varying degrees of commitment. Aerobic, which uses air to compost, is quick, but high maintenance because your heap needs frequent turning; anaerobic, both low-maintenance and very slow, is done without air and involves letting waste sit undisturbed for years; vermicomposting employs red worms, bacteria and insects to break down matter (medium maintenance and speed).
But, as Brett L. Markham points out in his excellent "The Mini Farming Guide to Composting" (Skyhorse Publishing), nature is on your side: No matter which method you choose, it's nearly impossible to screw this up. Why is this even a thing? Why are we still talking about east coast HSR in 2019 as if it’s a pressing national priority?
It’s not because there’s an obvious problem to be addressed. There’s already a regular public transport service operating on this route. It’s got adequate capacity and scope to scale up in line with demand. Importantly, it’s a competitive market with four major operators i.e. Qantas, Tiger, Jetstar and Virgin.
This isn’t like a new outer suburban growth area where there’s no rail access at all. East coast HSR is about replacing one form of public transport with another. That’d be fine except for the fact it hinges on provision of a mammoth subsidy.

my usual few items in a hand basket and took my wares to the cashier's counter. I set the basket on the table (not a conveyor belt, just a small table) and started to reach for my wallet.
I looked up and the cashier was just staring at the basket, not moving. I asked her if everything was OK, and she replied, "I never remove items from baskets."
I didn't realize that was a thing. I simply thought the effort to grab something from inside a basket was the same as it was on a table. I'm happy to learn the right way to be, so it wasn't a big deal to do as she wanted.
Got to thinking: Have I been a jerk all this time and not known? Facebook opinions were 50-50 on whether that's truly an etiquette thing or whether she was just cranky.

A Paris-based correspondent for Time magazine early in his career, Karnow was assigned in 1958 to Hong Kong as bureau chief for Southeast Asia and soon arrived in Vietnam, when the American presence was still confined to a small core of advisers. In 1959, Karnow reported on the first two American deaths in Vietnam, not suspecting that tens of thousands would follow.

executives break down the elements of a decision-making process and consider input from a range of participants. This type of approach is highly effective when used in brainstorming sessions and strategic planning meetings.
An individual decision tree should be used for each decision that must be made. Create the core or “trunk” for the tree using a whiteboard or large paper flipchart that is easy to write on and is visible to all participants. In the center of the core, briefly summarize the decision to be made. For example, if you are thinking about diversifying your product offerings, you would write “New product development?” in the core.
From the core of your tree, draw two main “branches” or lines that represent the pros and cons of the decision. Using the example of a new product introduction, pros might include increased earnings, entry into new markets and portfolio diversification. Cons could include financial risk and the necessary investment
